questions.text:
You see the senior resident ordering the following medications for a patient with end-stage kidney disease. What is the electrolyte abnormality that he is trying to correct?
  1. Intravenous calcium gluconate 
  2. Regular insulin with dextrose 
  3. Salbutamol nebulization
questions.solution:
The most likely electrolyte abnormality that is being corrected using the above is hyperkalemia.

Hyperkalemia is defined as a serum potassium level of more than 5.5 mEq/L. It can cause drastic conduction changes. It can be diagnosed by a sequence of changes affecting the ST-T segments and QRS complex. ST-T segment changes reflect a change in repolarization, while QRS complex changes reflect a change in depolarization.

The ECG changes that can be seen in hyperkalemia depend on the extent of hyperkalemia. 

S. No. Serum potassium level ECG change
1 5.5–6.5 mEq/L Tall, peaked T waves with 'tented' or 'pinched' shape
2 6.5–7.5 mEq/L Loss of P waves
3 7.0–8.0 mEq/L Widened QRS complex
4 > 8.0 mEq/L Sine wave

Drugs that cause hyperkalemia include the following:

  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers, e.g. losartan 
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor blockers like spirinolactone, eplerenone, and drospirenone
  • Epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) blockers like amiloride, triamterene, trimethoprim, pentamidine, and nafamostat

The most common cause of hyperkalemia is kidney failure. 

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following:

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate, which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective.
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose. The insulin will reduce the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. The dextrose will counteract the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Provide salbutamol nebulization, which will also shift potassium inside the cell.
  4. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis.

questions.text: The physician at the emergency department decides to perform endotracheal intubation on a patient. The physician administers  1mg/kg of a short-acting muscle relaxant and anticipates that the medicine's effects will set in within 60 seconds. This muscle relaxant is likely to be:
questions.solution:
The muscle relaxant is likely to be is suxamethonium/succinylcholine. It is the shortest-acting depolarising neuromuscular blocker.

It has a rapid onset (around 1 minute) and a short duration of action (typically less than 10 min). The duration of action is short due to rapid hydrolysis by the butyrylcholinesterase enzyme.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing & non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant: 

  • Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant:

Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes)

  • Gantacurium

Short-acting (10-20 minutes)

  • Mivacurium

 Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)

  • Atracurium
  • Cisatracurium
  • Vecuronium
  • Rocuronium

Long-acting (>50 minutes)

  • Pancuronium
  • Doxacurium

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of sudden onset chest pain that radiates to the left arm and jaw. He is profusely sweating. An ECG was taken immediately. Interpret his ECG.
questions.solution:
The patient has a myocardial infarction (MI) with ECG changes of a left bundle-branch block (LBBB), which can be identified by the following classical features:

  • Wide QRS complex- QRS ≥120 ms 
  • Predominantly negative (QS) complexes in lead V1 and entirely positive (R) complexes in lead V6.
  • M pattern seen in left chest leads (V5, V6) 

MI can have the following ECG changes:

  • ST-segment elevation- zone of injury
  • T wave depression
  • Deep Q waves- late sign to develop
  • New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of LBBB: Mnemonic WILLIAM (W pattern in V1-V2; L-LBBB; M pattern in V3-V6)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of RBBB: Mnemonic MARROW (M pattern in V1-V2; R-RBBB; W pattern in V3-V6)

questions.text: While prescribing levonorgestrel as post-coital emergency contraception, you would advise for ______.

choices.text: 5 mg single dose within 24 hours of unprotected intercourse
0.75 mg single dose within 24 hours of unprotected intercourse
3 mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse
1.5 mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse

questions.solution:
Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse can be used for emergency contraception. Alternatively, it can also be administered in two doses of 0.75 mg. 1st dose is taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse and the 2nd dose 12 hours apart. 

Emergency contraception refers to backup methods for contraceptive emergencies which women can use within the first few days after unprotected intercourse to prevent an unwanted pregnancy. Administration of postcoital contraceptive agents that interfere with postovulatory events that can lead to pregnancy. 

The various emergency contraceptive methods along with their mechanism of action have been described below:

  • IUCD (intrauterine contraceptive device) prevents the implantation of a fertilized ovum. It does so by acting as a foreign body within the uterine cavity. This leads to increased contractility, and tubal peristalsis, and promotes leukocytic infiltration in the endometrium. 
  • Ulipristal is given as a 30 mg tablet and should be taken within 5 days. It is a synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator. The drug attaches to the progesterone receptor, delays ovulation, and suppresses endometrium, thereby preventing implantation.
  • Ethinyl estradiol 50 μg + norgestrel 0.25 mg is administered as two tablets within 72 hours of coitus followed by the 2 tablets after 12 hours. The hormone may delay ovulation if taken soon after intercourse. 
  • Centchroman is administered as two tablets of 60 mg taken twice over a duration of 24 hours and within 24 hours of intercourse. It acts by preventing the implantation of the blastocyst in the endometrium. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text:
An obese and diabetic man presented with the lesions as shown below over his abdomen. On examination, he had diastolic hypertension. 24-hour urinary-free cortisol was increased. ACTH levels were high. What is the likely diagnosis?

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an obese, diabetic man with the image showing purple striae, diastolic hypertension, increased 24-hour urinary cortisol levels, and high levels of ACTH. So the likely diagnosis is Cushing's syndrome. 

Cushing's syndrome is a group of clinical features that occur due to chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids of any etiology. Cushing's disease is specifically Cushing's syndrome that occurs due to pituitary corticotrope adenoma. 

Typical features include

System Clinical features
Body fat
  • Central or truncal obesity (most common)
  • Buffalo hump (fat deposition behind the neck)
  • Moon facies  
Skin
  • Purple striae (over abdomen & flanks)
  • Acne and Hirsutism 
  • Easy bruising 
  • Facial plethora
  • Hyperpigmentation 
Musculoskeletal
  • Proximal myopathy
  • Osteoporosis
Metabolic
  • Poorly controlled hyperglycemia
  • Dyslipidemia
Reproductive
  • Low libido
  • Amenorrhea
Renal
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
CVS
  • Atherosclerosis 
  • Diastolic hypertension 
  • Edema 
Hematologic
  • Hypercoagulable state 
  • Neutrophilia
  • Eosinopenia
CNS
  • Depression, anxiety
  • Psychosis 
  • Irritability

 

Management of Cushing's syndrome includes

  • Surgical removal of the tumor followed by hydrocortisone replacement with gradual tapering is preferred.
  • Medical management includes metyrapone and ketoconazole. 

Other options:

Option A: Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency in which the adrenal is unable to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (glucocorticoid), and aldosterone (mineralocorticoid). The features are fatigue, weight loss, anorexia, low blood pressure, postural hypotension, hypoglycemia, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, salt craving, hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.

Option B: Adrenal crisis or acute adrenal insufficiency is an emergency usually occurring in patients with primary adrenal insufficiency. It is triggered by conditions like intercurrent illness and stress. The features include hypovolemic shock, acute abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, decreased responsiveness, stupor and coma.

Option C: Conn's syndrome or primary aldosteronism occurs due to aldosterone secreting adrenal adenoma leading to mineralocorticoid excess. It is characterized by hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, muscle weakness, proximal myopathy and muscle cramps.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Iatrogenic (Most common cause)

  • Exogenous administration of glucocorticoids

Endogenous Causes

  • ACTH Dependent – (90 % of endogenous causes)
  • Cushing’s disease – ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma
  • Ectopic ACTH syndrome – Due to ACTH secretion by
  • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
  • Small-cell lung cancer
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • ACTH Independent – (10% )
  • Adrenocortical adenoma
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of sudden onset headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. The patient has had multiple similar episodes in the past. During these episodes, the patient's blood pressure is elevated. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor of the sympathetic system arising from the adrenal medulla.

Patients commonly present with a classical triad of palpitation, headache, and profuse sweating. Patients also present with hypertension and cardiac arrhythmias. These symptoms are due to an excess of catecholamines secreted by the tumor.

Related Pearl: Pheochromocytoma

Features:

  • When pheochromocytoma is associated with the MEN syndrome it is rarely malignant.
  • Phaeochromocytomas are greyish-pink on the cut surface and are usually highly vascularised.
  • Zellbalen cells and nuclei with salt and pepper chromatin are seen.

Factors indicating more chances of malignancy:

  • An increased PASS (phaeochromocytoma of the adrenal gland scale score)
  • High number of Ki-67-positive cells
  • Vascular invasion or a breached capsule

Diagnosis:

  • Urinary catecholamine and VMA level assay are most sensitive screening test.
  • MRI is the IOC.
  • Biopsy and CT Contrast scan are contraindicated in order to avoid Hypertensive crisis.

Treatment:

  • Adrenalectomy is preferred TOC.
  • Size<5 cm -  Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Preop Alpha blockers should be given
  • Mitotane should be started as adjuvant or palliative treatment

 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Clinical triad:
    • Headaches – M/C symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension, sustained or paroxysmal – M/C Sign
  • Anxiety and panic attacks
  • Weight loss
  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Constipation
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis
  • Elevated blood sugar
  • Hypercalcemia

questions.text: Angel dust is a street name for which drug?
questions.solution:
Angel dust is the street name for phencyclidine. It is an NMDA antagonist.

Popular street names of abused drugs:

  • Phencyclidine(PCP)- Angel dust, peace pill
  • Marijuana- Pot, weed
  • Heroin- Smack
  • Cocaine- Crack
  • Methylenedioxymethamphetamine(MDMA)- Ecstasy, X
  • Flunitrazepam- Roofie, forget-me pill

questions.text: A case-control study was done among 500 lung cancer patients and 400 controls. In the study groups, 400 and 50 smokers were identified respectively. Calculate the odds ratio for this study:
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the odds ratio (OR) is 28, hence smoking acts as a risk factor for lung cancer. 

The given data is represented as: 

 

Disease +

Disease  -

Exposure +

400 (a)

50 (b)

Exposure -

100 (c)

350 (d)

Odds Ratio = ad/bc

= (400 x 350) / (50 x 100)

= (4 x 35)/5

= 4 x 7

= 28

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Odds ratio calculation (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • If the frequency of exposure is higher among cases, the OR will exceed 1, which indicates increased risk.
  • If the frequency is lower, then it will be <1, which can indicate possible protection.
  • If the OR is 1, then there is no association of risk with exposure or that the event is equally likely in both groups.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

  • In a case control study, progression is from effect to cause as outcome or disease has already occurred.
  • It is also called retrospective study.
  • Design of Case Control Study

 

    • Steps of Case Control Study
      • Selection of cases and controls
      • Matching
      • Measurement of exposure
      • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
    • Advantages and Disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Easy to carry out

Rapid and inexpensive

Requires few subjects

Used to investigate rare diseases

No risk to subjects

Different etiological factors can be studied.

Risk factors can be identified.

No attrition problems

Minimal ethical problems

Relies on memory or past records which can give rise to bias

Selection of appropriate control groups may be difficult.

Incidence cannot be measured.

Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors

Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis

Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the clinic with ascites. The serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) in the patient is found to be 1.4g/dL. Which among the following is the most likely cause of ascites in this patient?
questions.solution:
The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) ≥ 1.1g/dL suggests portal hypertension as the cause of ascites.

Serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin. 

It helps distinguish ascites caused by portal hypertension from other causes of ascites. 

 

SAAG ≥ 1.1g/dL - Ascites due to portal hypertension SAAG <1.1g/dL- Ascites due to nonportal causes
Ascitic protein <2.5g/dL Ascitic protein >2.5g/dL
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Pancreatitis
  • Peritoneal TB
  • Peritoneal carcinomatosis
  • Biliary leak. 
 
  • Cirrhosis
  • Late Budd Chiari syndrome
  • Massive liver metastases
  • Heart failure or constrictive pericarditis
  • IVC obstruction
  • Sinusoidal obstruction syndrome
  • Early Budd Chiari syndrome

questions.text:
A group of demographers studied the changes in the birth and death rates of two countries, A and B from the year 2001 to 2011. The collected data is given below. In which stages of the demographic cycle are countries A and B in respectively?

Country A:

  2001 2011
Birth rate 38.3 38.3
Death rate 13.7 10.2

Country B:

  2001 2011
Birth rate 12.4 12.3
Death rate 6.7 6.6
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, country A is in stage 2 and country B is in stage 4 of the demographic cycle. 

According to the given data, in country A, the high birth rate has remained unchanged with a decline in the death rate. This will result in an exponential increase in the population. This means country A is in the early expanding stage of the demographic cycle.

In country B, the low birth rate and death rates have remained unchanged. Thus, the population will attain a plateau phase and remain stationary. This means country B is in the low stationary stage of the demographic cycle.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Which of the following is Sims curette?
questions.solution:
The instrument marked as 1 in the image is Sims curette. 

It is a single-ended uterine curette used for dilatation and curettage.

It is designed to remove tough tissue from the lining of the uterus for biopsy or excision. The curette features a sharp loop tip to aid in the removal of uterine tissue.

 The image above shows the trolley with various instruments:

  1. Sims uterine curette
  2. Hegar dilator
  3. Sims uterine sound
  4. Karman's cannula - It is used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.
  5. Leech Wilkinson's cannula
  6. Rubin's cannula 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: Asbestos exposure is most commonly associated with which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Asbestosis is most commonly associated with Mesotheliomas. 

Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis that occurs after continuous exposure to asbestos. Asbestosis affects the basal part of the lung causing diffuse peribronchial fibrosis.

Other complications associated with asbestos exposure are:

  • Recurrent pleural effusions
  • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Mesothelioma
  • Laryngeal, ovarian and colon carcinoma
  • Increased incidence of autoimmune and cardiovascular diseases

questions.text: A patient presented with extensive burns and was started on ringer's lactate. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to assess adequate fluid correction in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate way to assess adequate fluid correction in a burn patient is by measuring urine output. 

The urine output should be maintained between 0.5 to 1mL/kg body weight/hour.

Urine output is an indicator of kidney perfusion, which is an indicator of overall organ perfusion. Maintaining organ perfusion is the primary goal of IV fluid therapy in burn patients. If the urine output is low and the patient presents with signs of hypoperfusion (restlessness with tachycardia, cool peripheries, high hematocrit). A bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be administered. 

Other options: 

Option A: The parkland formula is a tool to estimate fluid requirement, and not assess the adequacy of fluid correction.

Option B: Mean arterial blood pressure is measured when the patient has a complex burn with cardiac dysfunction. 

Option D: Hematocrit values are measured when overhydration or dehydration is suspected in complex burns.

questions.text: The image represents a treatment modality used in the management of cervical dysplasia. What is the name of this procedure?
questions.solution:
Loop electrosurgical excision procedure(LEEP) is the most commonly preferred outpatient treatment modality for high-grade cervical lesions.

LEEP can be done under local anesthesia and it is cost-effective, hence it is widely performed in an outpatient setting.

Unlike ablative procedures, LEEP also provides a histological specimen whose margins can be assessed.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

WHO grade CIN grade Description Bethesda  Treatment
Mild Dysplasia CIN I Dysplastic cells in lower 1/3 of cervix LSIL Colposcopic directed biopsy
Moderate Dysplasia CIN II Dysplastic cells up to 2/3 of cervix HSIL Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of cervix HSIL Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full thickness but basement membrane is intact HSIL  Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: A patient who is a tour guide on Mount Everest presented with blisters on her hand as shown in the figure below. She has severe pain and on examination is erythematous and tender. Which of the following is not used in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Apply heat to the area and cast as soon as possible

questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this patient is frostbite. Management does not involve the application of heat to the area and cast, as it is contraindicated in frostbite.

In frostbite, tissue damage results from severe environmental cold exposure or from direct contact with a very cold object. Tissue injury results from both freezing and vascular stasis. It usually affects the distal aspects of the extremities or exposed parts of the face, such as the ears, nose, chin, and cheeks.

Clinical features include decreased sensation (especially for pain, and temperature sensations) in the acral tips and extremities. The affected area appears waxy, mottled, or violaceous. Patients may have a wood-like sensation in the affected area.

Treatment:

  • Initial treatment is by rapid rewarming (or thawing), which is accomplished by immersion of the affected part in a water bath at temperatures of 37°–40°C (99°–104°F) for 30–60 min. Rewarming by exercise, rubbing, or friction is not advised. 
  • Analgesics such as ibuprofen are often required during rewarming.
  • Antithrombotics, thrombolytics, and vasodilators such as prostacyclin can be given to improve circulation after rewarming.
  • Frost bites are associated with an increased risk of infections and tetanus. Therefore, the injured area should be cleaned with soap or antiseptic, and sterile dressings should be applied. Tetanus prophylaxis must be given, but, empirical antibiotics are not recommended.
  • The patient must be monitored for the development of compartment syndrome.
  • Elective late amputation after imaging may be required in severe cases.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with fever, arthralgia, fatigue for the past six months, and new-onset hematuria. The patient has a rash on her face as shown in the image below. Urine examination reveals RBC casts and proteinuria. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of lupus nephritis.

Lupus nephritis is a common complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It results from immune complex deposition containing DNA and anti-DNA. 

Clinical features include proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension. The disease is divided into 6 classes based on severity. Patients with class V disease are at an increased risk of thrombotic complications. Lupus nephritis can result in end-stage disease warranting dialysis or transplantation.

SLE is an autoimmune condition more commonly seen in women. Antinuclear antibodies, anti-dsDNA, and anti-Sm are the autoantibodies implicated. Symptoms include maculopapular butterfly rash, photosensitivity, oral or nasal ulcers, fever, and intermittent polyarthritis. Pleuritis and pericarditis can also be associated. Systemic glucocorticoids, cyclophosphamide, or mycophenolate mofetil are used for management. Due to the possible teratogenic effects of these drugs, hydroxychloroquine is the mainstay in pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A - Acute interstitial nephritis is a type of acute kidney injury. It is marked by oliguria and raised creatinine. Various causes of interstitial injury include the use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), pyelonephritis, leukemia, and sepsis. White blood cell (WBC) casts and granular casts may be seen.

Option B - Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis usually affects male children between the age of 2-14. Skin or pharyngeal infection with M types of the organism is implicated. Symptoms include hematuria, pyuria, and hypertension. Flank pain and headache are also associated symptoms. Red blood cell (RBC) casts are seen in the urine.

Option D - IgA nephropathy arises due to mesangial IgA deposition. It is characterized by recurrent macroscopic hematuria after an upper respiratory infection associated with proteinuria. Mesangial proliferation is a distinctive feature. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and steroids can be used for management.

Related Pearl: Classification of Lupus Nephritis (International Society of Nephrology and Renal Pathology Society)

 

Class 

Findings

Minimal mesangial lupus nephritis (class I)

Immune complex deposition in the mesangium without structural changes by light microscopy.

Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II)

Mesangial cell proliferation, accumulation of mesangial matrix, and granular mesangial deposits of immunoglobulin and complement

Focal lupus nephritis (class III)

Involvement of fewer than 50% of all glomeruli.

Endocapillary proliferation associated with focal necrosis and crescent formation.

Diffuse lupus nephritis (class IV)

Most common and severe form of lupus nephritis

>50% glomeruli are affected.

Diffuse endocapillary and extracapillary proliferation with cellular crescents

“Wire loop” structures on light microscopy (Subendothelial deposits).

Membranous lupus nephritis (class V)

Diffuse thickening of the capillary walls due to deposition of subepithelial immune complexes.

Advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis (class VI)

Sclerosis of more than 90% of the glomeruli 

 

 

The image below shows extensive deposition of immune complexes in the thickened glomerular capillary loops in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), giving a "wire loop" appearance:

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 18-month-old son to OPD with complaints of repeated urinary tract infections. During diagnostic work-up, pelvic USG shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the USG showing the key-hole sign is suggestive of the posterior urethral valve (PUV). It is seen due to dilatation of the bladder and the proximal urethra.

The posterior urethral valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit, which lies just distal to the verumontanum. They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow.

The posterior urethral valve is the most common congenital cause of bladder outlet obstruction in males. PUV is classified into three types based on Young's classification.

Diagnosis is made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder. If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then neonates typically present with urinary infection or uremia and renal failure. 

The investigation of choice for a posterior urethral valve is micturating cystourethrography (MCUG).

Initially, the obstruction is relieved by catheterization to preserve renal function. Definitive treatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves with lifelong supportive treatment. 

The following MCUG shows vesicoureteric reflux due to posterior urethral valves:

questions.text: A female presents with hirsutism, delayed periods & obesity. USG findings are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasound image given below showing an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery(a string of pearls) is indicative of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. The Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS:

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities (oligo/amenorrhoea), anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography.

Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include ≥ 12 small cysts, an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. 

Management:

  • Weight reduction alone is beneficial in mild hirsutism and lifestyle changes (like smoking cessation) are advised in the management of PCOS.
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism.
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin. Acarbose can be used if metformin is contraindicated
  • Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. This is done either by laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrine levels and improves fertility.

Surgery is indicated only if,

  • Medical therapy fails
  • Hyperstimulation occurs
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

Other Options:

Option B: Molar Pregnancy will produce a characteristic Snowstorm appearance on ultrasound.

Option C: Enlarged ovaries meeting in the midline having large cysts are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Option D: The image below depicts multiple theca lutein cysts.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic with a history of binge drinking presents with an episode of vomiting bright red blood. His vitals are stable. What is the most probable diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the above-mentioned clinical presentation is Mallory Weiss tear as the patient's vitals are stable.

Mallory Weiss Syndrome:

  • It is a common cause of upper gastrointestinal bleeding due to the presence of longitudinal superficial mucosal lacerations (Mallory-Weiss tears).
  • They occur primarily in the lower esophagus close to the gastroesophageal junction.
  • It mainly occurs in patients with repetitive forceful retching and vomiting and is associated with heavy alcohol intake.
  • The concurrent presence of portal hypertension with esophageal varices and hiatal hernia in patients with Mallory Weiss syndrome is not uncommon.

Boerhaave syndrome:

  • It is a transmural perforation of the esophagus (while the Mallory Weiss tear is a mucosal tear).
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Mackler's Triad:
      • Vomiting
      • lower thoracic pain
      • subcutaneous emphysema
    • Other classical findings include deranged vitals tachypnea, tachycardia, fever, and hypotension.
    • Diaphoresis and abdominal rigidity can also be present

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the immunization programme?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a ten-year-old schoolchild will be administered the TT/Td vaccine according to the National Immunization Schedule.

The Tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen (d) as recommended for older children and adults. The MoHFW recommends the replacement of TT vaccine with Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5ml is administered in the intramuscular route in the upper arm.

Scheduled to be administered at 10 and 16 years of age.

For pregnant women :

  • Td-1: early in pregnancy
  • Td-2: 4 weeks after Td-1
  • Td (Booster): if pregnancy occurs within 3 years of last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

Other options:

Option A - According to the National Immunization Schedule, BCG should be given at birth or as early as possible up to 1 year of age. It provides protection against CNS and disseminated TB. A dose of 0.1 ml is administered intradermally in the left upper arm.

Option B - Measles/MR is given at 9 completed months (1st dose) and a second dose is given at 16-24 months. Measles can be given till 5 years of age. A dose of 0.5ml is administered subcutaneously in the right upper arm.

Option D - DPT vaccine is administered as a part of the pentavalent vaccine at the 6th, 10th and 14th weeks of life. DPT booster doses are administered at 16-24 months (first booster) and 5-6 years (second booster). It can be administered until 7 years of age (with booster doses). A dose of 0.5ml is administered in the anterolateral aspect of the mid-thigh. The 2nd booster dose can be administered in the upper arm.

questions.text: Which among the following is an oral cavity lesion with a  high-risk of malignant transformation?
questions.solution:
Speckled erythroplakia has a high risk of malignant transformation.

Malignancy risk:

High-risk lesions 

Erythroplakia (homogenous/speckled) 

  •  Seen as red velvety lesions
  •  Speckled type is the most  aggressive
  •  The treatment of choice is surgical ablation 

Proliferative verrucous leucoplakia

  • A white patchy lesion that cannot be rubbed off.
  • Speckled leucoplakia has an erythematous base
  • The treatment of choice is excision

Chronic hyperplastic candidiasis

  • White patches that can be rubbed off with a hyperaemic border.
  • Management includes prolonged treatment with topical antifungals or systemic antifungal therapy. If no improvement or if there are any signs of dysplasia, surgical excision is done.

Medium risk lesions

Oral submucous fibrosis

  • Hypersensitive reaction to betel nut product.
  • Other risk factors are - tobacco, chili, vitamin deficiency 
  • Clinical features - trismus, ankyloglossia, soreness, and burning sensation in the mouth.
  • Management includes antioxidants, intralesional triamcinolone, and surgical excision.

Syphilitic glossitis

  • Associated with tertiary syphilis

Speckled erythroplakia:

Low-risk lesions

Oral lichen planus 

  • Reticulate fine lace-like pattern.
  • Management is topical corticosteroids.   

Discoid keratosis congenita
Discoid lupus erythematosus

Image: Localized discoid lupus erythematosus of the scalp showing follicular plugging.

questions.text: An 80 year old woman presents with rapidly enlarging neck swelling, weight loss and hoarseness of voice. FNAC of the swelling reveals poorly differentiated follicular cells of the thyroid gland. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid is an undifferentiated aggressive carcinoma arising from follicular cells. It occurs commonly in elderly females. It is a very aggressive tumour of short duration.

Clinical features

Rapidly progressive swelling of the thyroid gland which causes stridor and hoarseness of voice due to tracheal obstruction, dysphagia and fixity to the skin.

Anaplastic carcinomas are poorly differentiated thyroid carcinomas with varied morphology including giant cells or spindle-shaped cells or both. There is minimal follicular differentiation with intratumoral necrosis

Tracheostomy and isthmectomy have got a role to relieve respiratory obstruction temporarily. Treatment is external radiotherapy, as usually thyroidectomy is not possible. The prognosis is poor.

questions.text: A female patient presents with breast abscess. Under antibiotic cover aspiration was attempted which failed to reveal any aspirate. The next step in management is _____

choices.text: Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected

questions.solution:
The latest guidelines for the management of breast abscess specify that multiple aspirations under antibiotic cover should be attempted before an incision and drainage is done. This often allows resolution without the need for an incision scar and also allows the patient to carry on breastfeeding.

In some conditions mentioned below, the breast abscess may be unresponsive to repeated aspirations and antibiotic cover. In such cases, incision and drainage is performed. The conditions include:

  • Presence of thick pus
  • Bacteria resistant to antibiotics
  • If just superficial part has been aspirated in the presence of a multiloculated abscess.
  • A non-healing breast abscess due to tuberculosis of breast or Inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, or an immunocompromised host.

questions.text: An elderly man was caught peeping into a bathroom window and watching a girl disrobe. During his psychiatric evaluation, he confessed that he attains sexual gratification when he watches people naked or while they are engaged in any sexual activity without their knowledge. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
Attaining sexual gratification after observing someone naked or engaged in sexual activity is called voyeurism. 

Voyeurism is also called scopophilia. It is more common in men. The voyeuristic act may be accompanied by masturbation. 

Paraphilias (perversions) are sexual stimuli or acts that are considered deviations from normal sexual behaviors. These are necessary for some people to experience arousal and orgasm. Individuals with paraphilias do not experience sexual pleasure through stimuli that are considered normal.

Other options:

Option A: In transvestism there is a sexual urge to dress in opposite-gender clothing as a means of arousal. It is diagnosed when these fantasies have been acted upon for at least six months. 

Option B: Coprophilia is attaining sexual pleasure by defecating on the partner or by being defecated on. An urge to eat feces (coprophagia) may also be seen. 

Option D: Frotteurism is characterized by the rubbing of genitals against the buttocks or any other parts of the body of a woman who is fully clothed. This is done to achieve an orgasm and usually occurs in crowded places.

*Note: Exhibitionism is characterized by a recurrent urge to expose the genitals to strangers. The anticipation of the exposure results in sexual excitement and orgasm.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13
years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a nonconsenting person

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for postpartum blues?
questions.solution:
Postpartum blues is common in mothers in the puerperal period and requires nothing more than education and support. It is characterised by a labile mood, sadness and subjective confusion. It is thought to be due to changes in hormone levels, the stress of childbirth and anxiety about the responsibilities of motherhood.

If symptoms last longer than 2 weeks, an evaluation for postpartum depression is needed.

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 12 weeks from delivery and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

 0.1-0.2% Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

questions.text: A football player was brought to the hospital after he suffered an ​injury caused by a lateral blow to the knee joint. MRI revealed a medial collateral ligament injury. Which other structure is most commonly associated with this type of injury?
questions.solution:
The medial collateral ligament injury is commonly associated with medial meniscus injury as they are components of the unhappy triad of O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triangle.

The medial meniscus is less mobile than the lateral, and it cannot as easily accommodate to abnormal stresses. This is why meniscal lesions are more common on the medial side than on the lateral.

The unhappy triad of O’Donoghue consists of injury to

  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Medial collateral ligament
  • Medial meniscus

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called as – O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triangle. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to lateral blow to the knee. It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

Image: Unhappy triad injury in MRI (after O'Donoghue) of the knee joint (PDW SPIR). Left to right: Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament, rupture of the medial collateral ligament, and inner meniscal tear (here complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man  who is a c/c smoker presents with increased shortness of breath. His Pulmonary function test values were FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 30% to 50%.
ABG analysis reveals pH - 7.24; pCO2 - 60 mm Hg, pO2- 52 mmHg, HCO3 - 27 mmol/L. What is the most probable underlying acid-base disorder?
questions.solution:
The underlying acid-base disorder is respiratory acidosis.

A c/c smoker with FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 30% to 50% can be 1042.

In COPD there is hypercapnia leading to increased H+ formation.

 

How to find if it acidosis/alkalosis:

Step 1: A pH of 7.24 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: A plasma HCO3- is 27 mEq/L is within normal limits. This is very likely to be due to compensation as it does not reflect the direction of the pH change.

Step 3: A pCO2 of 60 mmHg along with an acidotic pH signifies respiratory acidosis. 

Step 4: The expected compensatory increase in HCO3- can be calculated using the following formula:

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 X Δ PaCO2 (as COPD is a chronic condition and the presentation of the patient is not acute)

Thus, the increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x (60-40) = 8 mEq/L

Therefore expected HCO3- is 24 + 8 = 32 mEq/L.

The actual HCO3- measured is 27 mEq/L (which is less than the expected value) indicating that there could be a component of metabolic acidosis also.

But, the predominant disorder is respiratory acidosis and thus it is the best answer.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: In which part of the fallopian tube does fertilization occur?
questions.solution:
Fertilization usually occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube.

During ovulation, the ovum is released and it enters the fallopian tube. It is propelled towards the uterine cavity by the peristaltic action of the fallopian tubes. It can only be fertilized within 24 hours of ovulation.  If coitus takes place during this period, the spermatozoa swimming up into the tubes meet the ovum in the ampulla.

Related Pearl: Fallopian tube

Gross anatomy:

The fallopian tube is divided into the following parts:

  • Intramural/Interstitial portion:  
    • Intrauterine
    • The narrowest and shortest part
  • Isthmus:
    • The most common site for tubectomy
  • Ampulla:
    • The longest part
    • The most common site for - fertilization and ectopic pregnancy
  • Infundibulum:
    • The widest part

Histology:

The ampulla, isthmus and infundibulum are extrauterine. They're covered by three layers: 

  • Mesosalpinx - It is the peritoneal layer. Also called serosa.
  • Myosalpinx - It contains smooth muscle and has 2 layers:
    • Inner circular 
    • Outer longitudinal
  • Endosalpinx - It is the mucosal layer. It has the following features:
    • Numerous branching folds, filling the entire lumen
    • Basement membrane
    • Ciliated, columnar epithelium 
    • Peg cells - non-ciliated epithelium. They help in the capacitation of sperms.

questions.text: An oncologist orders a bone scan to assess for bony metastases in a 49-year-old woman with breast cancer.  Which of the following radioactive isotope is used?
questions.solution:
Technetium tagged to various substrates is used for bone scans.

The patient is injected with a small amount of radioactive material such as 600 MBq of technetium-99m-MDP and scanned with a gamma camera, a device sensitive to the radiation emitted by the injected material. MDP (methyl diphosphonate) adsorbs into the hydroxyapatite crystals and accumulates in the areas of active bone formation. 

Given below is a bone scan demonstrating bony metastasis in the pelvis.

questions.text: A female patient at 33 weeks of gestation was diagnosed with severe preeclampsia. The patient was given a loading dose of 14g MgSO4, followed by 5g intramuscularly every 4 hours in the alternate buttocks. Which regimen is being followed here?
questions.solution:
The regimen being followed here is Pritchard regimen.

Preeclampsia is a multisystem disorder of pregnancy characterized by hypertension and proteinuria.

Patients present with elevated blood pressure, proteinuria, thrombocytopenia, cerebral and visual symptoms, intrauterine growth restriction of the fetus, and pulmonary edema. Patients with severe preeclampsia eventually eclamptic convulsions.

Magnesium sulfate is an anticonvulsant used to manage severe preeclampsia and eclampsia. The following regimens are employed to administer magnesium sulfate.

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4g(20% solution) intravenously over 3-5 minutes
followed by 10g intramuscularly
(5g in each buttock)		 5g (50%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttocks
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4g IV slow over 15-20 minutes 1-2g/h IV infusion

questions.text: A patient presents to you with complaints of mass descending per vaginum for the past 6 months.  On examination, you notice a grade 3 uterovaginal prolapse and a decubitus ulcer over the prolapse. Which of the following is a cause for this decubitus ulcer and treatment?

choices.text: Venous congestion and reduction of the prolapsed part into the vagina and daily packing with glycerine and acriflavine

questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of pelvic organ prolapse with a decubitus ulcer. It is due to venous congestion and local circulatory changes. 

Friction, congestion and circulatory changes in the dependent part of prolapse cause keratinization and pigmentation of the vaginal mucosa, as well as ulceration of the prolapsed tissue with a clean edge.

Treatment includes the reduction of the prolapsed part into the vagina and daily packing with glycerine and acriflavine. Acriflavine is an antiseptic agent while glycerine is a hygroscopic agent. This helps in the healing of the ulcer within a week or two.

Complications of prolapse:

  • Kinking of the ureter with resulting renal damage can occur in procidentia and enterocele.
  • Chronic Urinary tract infection due to retention of urine in a cystocele, and can lead to upper renal tract infec­tion and renal damage.
  • Decubitus ulcer due to venous congestion and local circulatory changes.
  • Stress incontinence occurs when the internal urinary meatus and neck of the bladder descend below the level of pelvic floor muscles.
  • Cancer of the vagina can rarely occur over the decubitus ulcer and if the ring pessary is left in over a long period.

questions.text: All of the following are included in the first stage of labor, except ______.
questions.solution:
The encirclement of the largest head diameter by the vulval ring is called crowning. This occurs in the second stage of labor.

Cervical effacement and dilatation occur in the first stage of labor.

First stage of labor is divided into 2 phases:

Latent phase Active phase
The onset of true labor pain up to 5cm cervical dilatation  From ≥ 6cm cervical dilatation with regular uterine contractions
Duration: 10-12 hours (nullipara) 6-8 hours (multipara) Rate of cervical dilatation:
1.2 cm/hour (nullipara)
1.5 cm/hour (multipara)
Concerned with cervical effacement Concerned with cervical dilatation

 

Note: Clinically, the active phase of labor is considered from ≥6 cm of cervical dilatation. However, we begin plotting the partograph from 4 cm of cervical dilatation (in accordance with modified WHO Partograph).

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presented to the physician with complaints of heartburn and a sour taste in the mouth for the past 1 year. He was prescribed proton pump inhibitors, but the symptoms did not improve. What is the immediate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of dyspepsia not responding to PPIs. So the best management for this patient is endoscopy.

In case of an unexplained dyspepsia

  • If the patient is >60 years - Endoscopy is the investigation of choice 
  • If the patient is <60 years - A test for H.pylori infection is done (stool antigen and urease breath test) and eradication treatment is given. Endoscopy is done only if any one of the alarming signs are present.

Alarming signs

  1. Odynophagia or dysphagia
  2. Unexplained weight loss
  3. Massive GI bleeding
  4. Recurrent vomiting
  5. Jaundice
  6. Palpable mass or adenopathy
  7. Family history of GI malignancy

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with jerky movements of her extremities for the past 1 week. Her hands show a typical movement as shown in the image below. She also complains of pain in multiple joints. Physical examination is remarkable for jaundice. Which of the following is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with jaundice along with the clip showing a wing beating tremor is suggestive of Wilson's disease with decompensation. The gold standard for diagnosis is liver biopsy.

Wilsons disease is an autosomal-recessive disease, caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase. The characteristics features of wilsons disease include Hepatitis, cirrhosis, behavioral disturbances, wing beating tremor, sunflower cataract and KF rings.

The image below is that of a patient with a KF ring and a sunflower cataract:

Diagnosis:

  • Presence of KF rings
  • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
  • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy - Gold standard
  • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

Trientine and Zinc is the first choice of a drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease.

Other options: 

Option b : Serum ferritin is not used to diagnose wilson disease but rather serum ceruloplasmin is used.

Option c : 24 hour urinary copper excretion is used for diagnosis of wilsons disease but it is not a gold standard investigation.

Option d : Genetic testing is an important part of diagnosis of wilson disease but is not an gold standard investigation. Detection of biallelic pathogenic variants in ATP7B is identified by molecular testing.

questions.text: What is the ideal thickness of lead aprons to be worn by workers associated with radiographical procedures?
questions.solution: The lead apron to be worn by workers associated with radiographical procedures should contain 0.5 mm of lead.

questions.text: Who among the following patients with "Short Bowel Syndrome" are considered as net secretors?

choices.text: Less than 200 cm of residual jejunum
More than 200 cm of residual jejunum
Less than 100 cm of residual jejunum
More than 100 cm of residual jejunum

questions.solution:
Net secretors are those patients having less than 100 cm of residual jejunum.

The patients with "Short Bowel Syndrome" who have had in excess of 200 cm of small bowel resected together with colectomy (and usually have a jejunostomy), are divided into two groups:

  • Net absorbers:>100 cm of residual jejunum and they absorb more water and sodium from the diet that passes through the stoma. These patients can be managed without supplementary parenteral fluids.
  • Net secretors: <100 cm of residual jejunum and loose more water and sodium from their stoma. These patients require supplements.

questions.text: A male patient with a history of chronic smoking presents with the complaint of dysphagia. Out of the following, which type of lung cancer is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
In heavy smokers, the most common types are small-cell lung cancers and squamous cell carcinoma. 

Small cell carcinomas have the strongest association with smoking. The most common lung cancer in lifetime non-smokers, light smokers (<10 pack-year history), women, and younger adults (<60 years) is adenocarcinoma. Smoking is a major risk factor for developing lung cancer. Other risk factors that can contribute are industrial chemical exposure, air pollution, etc.

WHO classification of lung carcinomas:

The WHO classification system divides epithelial lung cancers into four major cell types:

  • Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC)
  • Non-small-cell lung carcinomas (NSCLCs)
    • Adenocarcinoma
    • Squamous cell carcinoma
    • Large-cell carcinoma

SCLC may be distinguished from NSCLC by the presence of neuroendocrine markers including CD56, neural cell adhesion molecule (NCAM), synaptophysin, and chromogranin.

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

 Keratinization, squamous pearls, intercellular bridges Small cells, scant cytoplasm, salt and pepper chromatin, Azzopardi effect
IHC Mucin, TTF-1, Napsin-A p40, p63

Chromogranin, Synaptophysin, and CD56

questions.text: Which of the following indicators is used to calculate both Human Development Index (HDI) and Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI), according to WHO?
questions.solution:
Literacy is used in the measurement of both HDI and PQLI.

The components of the Human Development Index (HDI) include life expectancy at birth, literacy, and standard of living.

Human Development Index (HDI) is a measure of a country's average achievements in three dimensions of human development:

  • A long and healthy life, as measured by life expectancy at birth
  • Knowledge (literacy), as measured by mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling, and
  • A decent standard of living, as measured by GNI (gross national income) per capita

HDI values range from 0 to 1, with 1 as the maximum value.

Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy, and infant mortality rate are components of the Physical quality of life index (PQLI).

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

 

Human Development Index

[HDI]

Physical Quality of Life Index [PQLI]

Components

1.   Longevity (Life expectancy at birth)

2.  A decent standard of living (Real GNI per capita in PPP US$)

3.      Knowledge (Mean years of schooling; Expected years of schooling)

 

1.      Life expectancy at 1 year of age

 

2.      Infant Mortality rate

 

3.      Literacy rate

Range

0 to +1

0 to 100

 India currently ranks 132 (HDI is 0.633) on the 2021-2022 Human developmental Index.

questions.text: A  27 year old male presents with multiple hemangioblastomas,pheochromocytoma,multiple renal and pancreatic cysts with similar problems in his brother, aunt, and father.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario of multiple hemangioblastomas,pheochromocytoma,multiple renal and pancreatic cysts with family history is most likely to be von Hippel- Lindau disease.

It is an autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by the development of highly vascularized tumors in multiple organs. These include:

  • Haemangioblastomas of the retina and central nervous system
  • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Renal cysts- develop into clear renal cell cancer.
  • Pancreatic cysts
  • Ovary cystadenoma
  • Epididymal cystadenoma

questions.text: A  primigravida in her 10th week of gestation presents with spotting. On examination, the uterine size corresponds to 12 weeks. Transvaginal ultrasound was done and is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture along with the image is suggestive of a hydatidiform mole. The ultrasonography (USG) image shows the characteristic snowstorm appearance seen in a complete mole. It refers to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces.

Hydatidiform mole is an abnormal condition of the placenta, characterized by partly degenerative and partly proliferative changes in the villi. It is a gestational trophoblastic disease. Hydatidiform moles may be either partial or complete:

Classical clinical features of a complete mole:

  • Abnormal vaginal bleeding
  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Features of early-onset preeclampsia
  • Uterus appears large for date
  • Absent fetal parts and FHS
  • Expulsion of vesicular tissues (grape-like vesicles)
  • Theca lutein cyst of ovaries of more than 6 cm
  • Hyperthyroidism (rare)
  • Serum hCG > 100,000 mIU/ml
  • USG - snowstorm appearance

The definitive management after diagnosis is suction and evacuation, after making the cervix favorable.

Other options:

Option A: Blighted ovum (silent miscarriage) occurs when a fertilized egg implants in the uterus but does not develop into an embryo. It is a sonographic diagnosis where there is an absence of a fetal pole in a gestational sac with a diameter of 3 cm or more.

Option B: Missed abortion is when the fetus is dead and retained inside the uterus for a variable period. USG shows an empty sac early in the pregnancy or the absence of fetal cardiac activity and fetal movements.

Option C: Ectopic pregnancy is one in which the fertilized ovum is implanted and develops outside the normal endometrial cavity. The majority of ectopic pregnancies occur in the fallopian tube, the ampulla being the most common site.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XXX or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: A patient presents to the medicine outpatient department with a report showing significantly elevated thyroid stimulating hormone and low levels of free T4. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is primary hypothyroidism.

In patients with primary hypothyroidism, the thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) levels are elevated with low-normal levels of free T4.

Central hypothyroidism/secondary hypothyroidism is characterized by low-normal levels of T4 and low-normal levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone. This disease is due to a decrease in thyroid hormone secretion secondary to a disorder of the pituitary/hypothalamus.

Patients with subclinical hypothyroidism present with elevated serum TSH levels and normal free T4 levels.

questions.text: As a first-year dermatology resident, you see a patient with the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cicatrizing alopecia, flat-topped, purple, polygonal, papules and plaques on the flexural aspect of the wrist, Wickham's striae on the lips, longitudinal ridging, and thinning of nails are features of lichen planus.

Mucous membrane lesions are very common in lichen planus, occurring in almost 30–70% of cases. It is mostly seen on the tongue and buccal mucosa and also on the genitals and anal mucosa.

White streaks forming a lacework in buccal mucosa are a characteristic feature and are known as Wickham’s striae.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with a swelling that has been slowly growing in the past 2 years. On examination, it was variable in consistency and fully mobile. Which of the following statements regarding this tumour is true?

choices.text: The deep lobe is most commonly affected
Most common salivary gland tumor in adults.
Open biopsy is the gold standard investigation of choice
Facial nerve is commonly involved in this condition

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image depicts a case of pleomorphic adenoma. The only true statement regarding pleomorphic adenoma is that it is the most common salivary gland tumor in adults.

Pleomorphic adenoma:

  • Most common benign salivary gland tumor.
  • The most commonly affected gland is the parotid gland. 
  • The superficial lobe is most commonly affected.
  • Also called the mixed tumor, since it has both epithelial and mesenchymal components.

Clinical features:

  • Most commonly affects females around 40 years of age.
  • Most common presenting feature – painless swelling below, in front and behind the ear.
  • The involvement of the deep lobe leads to dumbbell tumour – swelling in both the neck and oral cavity.

Specific features:

  • Slowly growing benign tumour with painless swelling
  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard consistency and well-defined margins
  • Free from deeper structures with no facial nerve involvement
  • The deep lobe pushes tonsils and faucial pillars

Diagnosis:

  • FNAC – investigation of choice. 
  • Open biopsy contraindicated due to chances of injury to the facial nerve and seedling of the tumour (Option-C)

Treatment: Surgery is the mainstay of treatment - Superficial parotidectomy (Patey's operation). Radiotherapy is considered in high-grade malignancies demonstrating extra-glandular disease, perineural invasion , direct invasion of surrounding tissue, or regional metastases.

Note: Malignant change occurs in about 1.5 to 9.5% of cases of pleomorphic adenoma and is referred to as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma.

Symptoms suggestive of malignant transformation:

  • Rapid growth
  • Pain
  • Paraesthesias
  • Enlarged cervical lymph nodes
  • Restriction of jaw movements
  • Facial weakness
  • Skin invasion
  • Fixation of the mastoid tip.

Pathology:

Gross features:

  • The tumors are rounded, well-demarcated, measuring <6 cm in greatest dimension.
  • They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate.
  • The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma.

 

Microscopic features:

  • The epithelial elements resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells. They are arranged as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, strands, or sheets of cells.
  • These epithelial elements are dispersed within a background of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing islands of cartilage and, rarely, foci of bone.

The image below shows pleomorphic adenoma of the salivary gland consisting of mixed epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right).

questions.text: You observe a forensic surgeon doing en masse removal of organs during an autopsy. Which of the following autopsy techniques is he performing?
questions.solution:
The en masse removal of organs is done in the Letulle technique.

It is the removal of the cervical, thoracic, abdominal and pelvic organs as a single organ mass. They are subsequently dissected into organ blocks. 

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Rokitansky technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. Larynx and trachea are pulled downward, and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Ghon technique: Like the Rokitansky method, the Ghon method also employs the bloc method of removing thoracic, cervical, abdominal organs. However, the organs are removed 'en bloc', rather than with in-situ dissection. 
  • Letulle technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: A young female patient presents to the outpatient department with oligomenorrhea, acne, and increased facial hair. Which of the following is not an expected finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Streak ovaries/gonads are a characteristic finding in patients with Turner's syndrome. It is not seen in polycystic ovarian syndrome(PCOS).

Polycystic ovarian syndrome(PCOS) is an endocrinopathy characterized by anovulation, insulin resistance, clinical signs of androgen excess, and multiple ovarian cysts. Patients with this disorder present with oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea, increased facial hair, and acne. Other features that can be seen in this condition are dyslipidemia, obstructive sleep apnea, acanthosis nigricans, hair loss, and an increased risk of endometrial cancer. 

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone >2 ng/mL, free T >2.2 pg/mL (Normal level 0.2–0.8 ng/mL)
    • Normal androstenedione level is 1.3–1.5 ng/mL
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the primary survey?

choices.text: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
Taking CT scan of the patient

questions.solution:
Taking a CT scan of the patient is a part of secondary survey.

Primary survey is used to identify and manage the most immediately life-threatening pathologies first. 

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

ABCDE of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate)
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control haemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion)
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation)
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

Adjuncts to the primary survey:

  • Blood - FBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • Two wide-bore cannulae for intravenous fluids
  • Urinary and gastric catheters
  • Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit.
  • Radiographs of the cervical spine, chest AP view and pelvis AP view are done when necessary.
  • When required, all these x rays must also be done in pregnant women.

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at term is admitted to the labor room for normal vaginal delivery. A per vaginal examination was performed and a pulsatile cord-like structure was felt. An immediate ultrasound revealed the baby was still alive. What is the definitive management in this case?

choices.text: Manual elevation of the fetal presenting part

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of cord prolapse and the definitive management in this condition is delivery of the baby by cesarean section.

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is the delivery by cesarean section when the baby is alive and mature as in this clinical scenario. Reconfirming if the baby is alive before the incision is important to prevent unnecessary trauma from surgery.

The contraindications of immediate delivery are fetal death, lethal fetal anomalies, and a pre-viable gestation.

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is the delivery by the caesarian section. Till then, the following first aid measures can be carried out:

  • IV fluids, oxygen by face mask, and continuous fetal monitoring.
  • Stop oxytocin, if ongoing.
  • Manual elevation of the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the whole hand through the vagina.
  • Positioning of the patient in a steep Trendelenburg position, exaggerated Sim’s position, or knee-chest position.
  • Vagos method: Foley catheter is placed and the bladder is filled with 500-750 mL of saline, and then clamped. The patient’s enlarging bladder provides upward pressure on the fetus and alleviates the compression on the cord.
  • Funic reduction: Gentle manual repositioning of the cord into the uterus. It is not preferred nowadays.
  • Tocolysis can be considered if there is a prolonged interval before delivery

Sims postion:

Trendelenburg position:

Knee Chest position:

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of secondary syphilis?
questions.solution:
Moth-eaten alopecia is a feature of secondary syphilis.

Secondary syphilis is a stage of syphilis characterized by skin and mucous membrane manifestations. Rashes seen in secondary syphilis have three standard features:

  • They do not itch
  • They are coppery red in appearance
  • Rashes are symmetrical in distribution

Patients with secondary syphilis present with patchy, scattered hair loss affecting the eyebrows and beard. This pattern is termed moth-eaten alopecia.

The image below is that of a man with moth-eaten alopecia.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

  • Primary Syphilis:

Chancre- Painless, indurated, usually single

Lymphadenopathy- Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes

Dory flop sign- As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.

 

Secondary Syphilis:

A & B: Generalized rash(non-itchy, no vesicles, and palm and sole involvement).

This is the most common lesion.

C & D: Condyloma lata.

E: Moth-eaten alopecia (Non-scarring)

F: Mucous patches(Flat erosions on the tongue which can coalesce and form snail track ulcers).These are the most infectious lesions.

G: Pigmentary plaques

H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions

Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

 

Tertiary Syphilis:

Gummatous syphilis(deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor)

Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  

CVS-Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta

CNS-General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

 

Latent Syphilis-Period between secondary and tertiary syphilis, when the patient is asymptomatic clinically, and only serological evidence of infection is present.

  • Early latent- Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent- After 1 year of infection

questions.text: A trucut biopsy is obtained from a woman who presented with a breast lump. The biopsy confirms the presence of mucinous carcinoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for estrogen receptors, progesterone receptors, and HER2/neu receptors. What is the molecular subtype of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Cancer with ER, PR +ve and Her2/neu +ve status will be classified as luminal B type. It is also known as triple-positive cancer. 

Note: Expression of estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) in breast cancer cells is mainly assessed by immunohistochemistry. Staining of ≥1% of cells is considered positive.

Along with ER, PR, and Her2/neu, a proliferation index known as the Ki67 index is also used. Increased expression of Ki67 indicates increased proliferation of the tumor cells.
