(High/Low Ki)
Basal cell (worst prognosis)

(High Ki), Positive for myoepithelial markers - EGFR, CK 5,6,17

questions.text: A 50 year old smoker presents with pain along the left arm and ptosis. His chest radiograph shows a soft tissue opacity at the left lung apex with destruction of adjacent ribs. This is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of a pancoast tumour (superior sulcus tumour).

Pancoast syndrome/superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots, stellate ganglion, and the chest wall. It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs. Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis.

Regional spread can cause

  • Tracheal obstruction
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve palsy with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis)

questions.text: What is the largest fund for population and reproduction-related programs?
questions.solution:
United Nations Population Fund or formerly known as United Nations Fund for Population Activities(UNFPA), is the largest fund for sexual and reproductive health activities.

The goals of UNFPA are:  

  • To support reproductive health care for the women and the youth  
  • To help pregnant women, especially the ones who face maternal complications
  • Provide access for all to modern contraceptives.
  • Provide training for health workers to ensure childbirths are supervised by skilled attendants
  • Prevention of gender-based violence and female genital mutilation
  • Prevention of teen pregnancies and ending child marriage
  • Delivery of safe birth supplies, dignity kits, and other materials to survivors of conflict and natural disaster
  • Collection of data, census and analyze them for development and planning.  

The Resources and Funding are divided into core resources and non-core resources.

Core resources are used to effectively provide essential sexual and reproductive health services to those in need and in crisis.

Non-core resources include thematic funds such as UNFPA Supplies, the Maternal and New-born Health Thematic Fund, the Humanitarian Action Thematic Fund, Population Data Thematic Fund, and other funds which are goal-based. Some of the others include regional, issue-based or multi-country programs and initiatives.

questions.text: A 30-year-old psychiatric patient consumed some liquid from a bottle accidentally. Clinical examination shows a peculiar rash as shown in the image. What is the likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic boiled lobster appearance. It is seen in poisoning with boric acid.

In severe poisoning with boric acid, a beefy red skin rash, most often affecting palms, soles, buttocks, and scrotum, is seen. The intense erythema is followed by extensive exfoliation.

Boric acid is used as an antiseptic and insecticide.

questions.text: A pregnant patient in the later second trimester presents to the outpatient department with complaints of painless vaginal bleeding. She is diagnosed with the condition depicted in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image represents placenta previa.

Placenta previa is a condition characterised by partial or complete implantation of the placenta over the lower uterine segment. Patients commonly present with complaints of painless vaginal bleeding near the end of the second trimester or the third trimester.

The grades of placenta previa are:

  • Type—I (Low-lying): A significant portion of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and there is no encroachment of the os
  • Type—II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type—III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially.
  • Type—IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

questions.text: The wound in the given image is most likely to have been produced by?
questions.solution:
The image shows 'tram-line' bruising, most likely to have been produced by a stick or a broom handle. 

Tram-line bruising:

  • When the skin surface is struck by a rod or rectangular sectioned object such as a cane or lath, the consequent bruising may be of the ‘tram-line’ or ‘railway line’ type.
  • The mechanism of this double line is that the weapon sinks into the skin on impact so that the edges drag the skin downwards and the traction tears the marginal blood vessels. The centre compresses the skin, which, in the absence of underlying bone, causes little or no damage to the vessels.

questions.text: A middle age male patient presented with complaints of palpitations. The patient's ECG tracing is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient with ECG showing irregularly irregular rhythm is atrial fibrillation.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a type of cardiac arrhythmia characterized by disorganized, rapid, and irregular atrial activation. It is common in men and risk factors are age, underlying cardiac disease, hypertension, diabetes, family history of AF, and obesity.

Features include heart rate typically ranging from 110-160 beats/minute. It is irregular and rapid. Presyncope and syncope can be seen. Thrombus formation can occur and thromboembolic events can take place.

Typically, ECG shows an irregularly irregular rhythm with absent p waves.

Management is mainly by controlling rate and rhythm, avoiding the thromboembolism risk and modifying risk factors. 

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

 

Ventricular flutter

 

Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text:
What is the cause of LH surge?

FSH: Follicle-stimulating Hormone

LH: Luteinizing hormone
questions.solution:
Estradiol causes LH surge. Estradiol concentrations of 200 pg/mL for 50 hours are necessary to initiate this LH surge.

Phases of the menstrual cycle :

Follicular phase (days 0–14)

  • A higher FSH level at the beginning of this phase is responsible for the recruitment of the follicle cohort that contains the follicle destined for ovulation. A primordial follicle develops to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles.
  • LH receptors are up-regulated in theca and granulosa cells. During the mid-follicular phase, follicles produce greater amounts of estrogen and inhibin.
  • Estradiol levels increase and cause proliferation of the uterus.
  • FSH are suppressed by the negative feedback effect of estradiol and inhibin on the anterior pituitary.

Ovulation (day 14)

  • A burst of estradiol synthesis at the end of the follicular phase has a positive feedback effect on the secretion of LH (LH surge). There is a small preovulatory rise in progesterone concentrations generates an FSH level surge, which occurs with the LH surge.
  • Ovulation occurs as a result of the estrogen-induced LH surge.

Luteal phase (days 14–28)

  • Ovulation is assumed to have occurred if the progesterone level exceeds 3 nglmL on cycle day 21. Progesterone levels are high in this phase.
  • The corpus luteum begins to develop, and it synthesizes estrogen and progesterone. Vascularity and secretory activity of the endometrium increase to prepare for the receipt of a fertilized egg.
  • If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses at the end of the luteal phase. As a result, estradiol and progesterone levels decrease abruptly.

Menses (days 0–4)

  • The endometrium is sloughed because of the abrupt withdrawal of estradiol and progesterone.

A schematic diagram of the menstrual cycle and the changes occurring are shown below:

questions.text: The following set of instruments are used for which procedure?
questions.solution:
The given set of instruments are commonly used for the collection of pap smears. The given image includes Cusco's bivalved self-retaining speculum, Koplin's jar, smear slides, Ayer's spatula, and endocervical brush. 

Pap/ Papanicolaou test is a screening test only. The presence of abnormal cells/ a positive test requires further evaluation by colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage.

Prerequisites:

  • Should be done prior to vaginal examination.
  • Lubricants should not be used.
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test.
  • The ideal time is around ovulation.
  • The patient should not have had intercourse in the 24hrs prior to the test.

Screening guidelines:

  • Time for initiation: 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse.
  • Women aged 21-29 years: Every 3 years(earlier it was done annually)
  • Women who are aged 30-65 years: Pap test + HPV testing every 5 years.
  • Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious PAP, screening till 75 years.
  • HIV+ women: annual checkup until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.
  • HPV DNA testing in combination with PAP improves the sensitivity of screening.

Ayres spatula and endocervical brush are the instruments used for the pap test.

 

 

Hysteroscopy is the process of inspection of the uterine cavity. 

Indications:

Diagnostic:

  • Endocervical study in suspected endocervical malignancy, preinvasive cancer, and biopsy
  • Uterus—malformations, endometrial TB, Asherman syndrome, misplaced IUCD, menorrhagia, intermenstrual, bleeding submucous fibroid, polyp
  • Falloscopy

Therapeutic:

  • Endometrial polypectomy
  • Submucous fibroid
  • Septate uterus
  • Asherman syndrome
  • Removal of IUCD
  • Tubal sterilization
  • Balloonoplasty
  • IVF Intrafallopian insemination

The image shows the procedure of hysteroscopy and the common instruments used for the same.

 

Biopsy:

To take biopsy we commonly use Gellhorn's punch biopsy forceps as shown in the image below. It is used to take biopsies from the cervix.

 

Dilatation and curettage:

Instruments used in D&C:

  • Sim’s speculum: It retracts the posterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
  • Anterior vaginal wall retractor: Retracts the anterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix.
  • Vulsellum or Allis forceps: To hold the anterior lip of the cervix
  • Uterine sound: Simpson's uterine sound is a 30 cm long angulated instrument with a handle at one end and a rounded blunt tip at the other.
    It is used to measure the length of the uterus. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement
  • Cervical dilators: 
    • Hegar's dilator is a double-ended dilator used to dilate the cervix.
    • Hawkins’ single-ended dilator 
    • Fenton’s dilator
  • Curette:
    • Sim's curette is a single-ended curette
    • Blake's curette is a double-ended curette

 

The image above shows the trolley with various instruments:

  1. Sim's uterine curette
  2. Hegars dilator
  3. Sim's uterine sound
  4. Karman's cannula - It is used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.
  5. Leech Wilkinson's cannula
  6. Rubin's cannula 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

questions.text: All of the following are good prognostic factors in schizophrenia except:
questions.solution:
Insidious onset of symptoms is a poor prognostic factor of schizophrenia.

Prognostic factors of Schizophrenia: 

Good prognostic factors Poor prognostic factors
Acute onset Insidious onset
Late-onset Early-onset
Presence of stressor Absence of a stressor

Good premorbid social, sexual, and work histories

Poor premorbid social, sexual, and work histories
Presence of depression No depression
Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Family history of mood disorder Family history of schizophrenia
Married Single, divorced, widowed
 

Withdrawn, autistic behaviour
   No remissions in 3 years
  History of Perinatal Trauma
  History of assaultiveness

questions.text: A patient visits your clinic for follow-up after a breast surgery. She undergoes an x-ray scan, the findings of which are given below. Which of the following complications, if present in this patient, would show the linguine sign on MRI?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows silicone breast implants in a patient. MRI showing the linguine sign in post-silicone breast implant patients indicates intra-capsular silicone rupture.

After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around the implant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by the fibrous scar, while the shell appears as a group of wavy lines. This has been termed the linguine sign. It is seen in intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant.

Multiple hyperintense foci on T2-weighted images are sometimes found within the implant lumen. These findings are referred to as the “salad oil sign” or “droplet sign”.

Intracapsular rupture on MRI.

Breast implants are technically simple and it facilitates achieving symmetry. The implant in submuscular plane is better whenever a muscle is not removed during surgery. If the muscle is removed as in radical mastectomy, then a subcutaneous implant is placed. Silicone gel implants are used.

Complications may include pain, exposure of implant and rupture, infection, calcifications, displacements, intracapsular or extracapsular rupture and silicone granulomas.

MRI  of the breast can be used in the following cases:

  • To detect scar recurrence in women with a history of conservative breast surgery  
  • To assess the extent of high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)
  • To assess multifocality and multicentricity in lobular cancer 
  • It is the best imaging modality for women with breasts implants
  • As a screening tool in high-risk women with a positive family history.

Generally, ultrasound(USG) is the preferred modality of imaging in suspected cases of extracapsular rupture. The Snowstorm sign on USG is seen in extracapsular rupture. (Option-B)

Other options:

Option B: In the case of extracapsular rupture of the silicone implant, it is detected by snowstorm appearance on USG.

Option C: Risk of anaplastic large cell lymphoma of scar tissue is increased in breast implant patients. This is confirmed by biopsy.

Option D: Calcifications in post-implant surgery patients can be detected on X-ray film. MRI used to detect contractures.

The given image below shows the siliconoma on silicone breast implants and the HP section shows silicone granulomas following silicone leak:

questions.text: A patient with a history of blunt abdominal trauma presents to the emergency with abdominal pain. On examination his vitals were HR-122, BP-80/50 mmHg, SpO2-94%, and there were abdominal guarding and rebound tenderness. What is the initial step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Get a CECT abdomen to rule out intraperitoneal bleed
Get a USG FAST to rule out intraperitoneal bleed

questions.solution:
The history of blunt abdominal trauma, hypotension, abdominal guarding, and rebound tenderness is diagnostic of an intra-abdominal bleed. Since he is haemodynamically unstable, the initial management of this patient is to resuscitate him with intravenous crystalloids. 

A patient with blunt abdominal trauma who is haemodynamically unstable needs urgent exploratory laparotomy to control the bleeding. But the initial management and evaluation are directed at ATLS protocols based on Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability and Exposure, thus the first step is to stabilize him with IV fluids. In a hemodynamically unstable patient with abdominal trauma, the initial step is to start resuscitation with intravenous crystalloids. This helps restore intravascular volume, improve blood pressure, and stabilize the patient's condition before proceeding with further diagnostic evaluations or interventions.

The management of abdomen trauma depends on the hemodynamic status and the examination findings. Some major indications for laparotomy:

  • Peritonitis
  • Hemodynamic instability with positive FAST
  • Hollow organ injury
  • Stab wound with evisceration
  • Shock from uncontrolled bleeding

In a patient with hemodynamic instability and no signs of peritonitis, focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) is performed. If FAST is not available, then a diagnostic peritoneal lavage is done. The presence of intraabdominal bleeding on either necessitates further exploration.

If the patient is hemodynamically stable with no signs of peritonitis, then a contrast-enhanced CT scan is done to look for intra-abdominal injuries and decide on the need for operative, nonoperative, or angiographic therapy. In a patient with trauma and signs of peritonitis, an exploratory laparotomy is done. 

The most common organs that are affected in blunt abdominal trauma are the spleen followed by the liver. Blood should be urgently typed and transfused in case of unstable patients with large bleeds when needed.

questions.text: Which intravenous fluid is preferred for the hydration of patients with pre-renal acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
Isotonic crystalloids like 0.9% NaCl are preferred for the correction of hypovolemia in pre-renal AKI.

Management of AKI:

1. AKI care bundle:

  • Nephrotoxic drugs should be avoided and the dosage of other drugs must be adjusted according to kidney function
  • Creatinine levels and urine output must be closely monitored

2. Hemodynamic management:

  • If hypovolemic - fluid replenishment using isotonic crystalloids (normal saline)
  • If euvolemic - fluid intake = urine output + additional ~500 mL 
  • If hypervolemic - diuretics are administered. If the response is unsatisfactory, dialysis is required.

3. Management of complications:  

  • Pulmonary edema - Treated with diuretics, non-invasive ventilation, and dialysis if refractory
  • Metabolic acidosis - Treated when pH <7.2 with oral or IV sodium bicarbonate
  • Hyperkalemia - Treated by restriction of dietary potassium, administration of sodium polystyrene sulfonate, insulin, glucose, inhaled β-agonist, and calcium gluconate

Options A and B: Hydroxyethyl starch solutions and dextrans increase the risk of severe AKI and are contraindicated.

Option D: Ringer's lactate is preferred only when a large volume of fluids is required.

questions.text: What is the ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation?
questions.solution:
Nuchal translucency evaluation, a component of first-trimester aneuploidy screening, is done between 11-14 weeks.

It represents the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue, overlying the fetal spine, at the back of the neck. When the nuchal translucency is increased, the risk of fetal aneuploidy and structural anomalies such as heart defects is significantly elevated.

First trimester aneuploidy screening combines two maternal serum analytes and a sonographic measurement:

  1. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
  2. Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A)
  3. Nuchal translucency (NT)

It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation. In cases of fetal Down syndrome, the first-trimester serum-free β-hCG level is higher and the PAPP-A level is lower. With trisomy 18 and trisomy 13, levels of both analytes are lower.

Note: Nuchal fold is a normal fold of skin seen at the back of the fetal neck during the second trimester of pregnancy. Increased nuchal fold thickness is associated with fetal aneuploidy.

questions.text: A patient presented with weight loss and easy fatiguability.  A bone marrow aspirate is shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing faggot cells are suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

AML is a hematopoietic progenitor malignancy that causes immature myeloblast accumulation in the bone marrow. Occupational exposure to benzene leads to epoxide formation which in turn predisposes to the development of AML. Clinically, the patients present with symptoms resulting due to pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia). There is generalised fatigue, bone pain, bleeding tendencies and an increased risk of recurrent infections. Hemorrhagic complications such as disseminated intravascular coagulation may be seen more commonly in a subtype of AML, acute promyelocytic leukemia.

Other distinctive features of AML include

  • Bone marrow/peripheral smear shows a large, uniform population of cells (myeloblasts) with prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow). It shows the presence of primary cytoplasmic granules
  • Auer rods: needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by the fusion of lysosomes. (black arrow)
  • Multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks known as faggot cells (seen in peripheral smear). This is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (AML M3) or AML associated with PML-RARɑ fusion gene or t(15;17). Other cytogenetic abnormalities, seen in AML are t(8;21) and inversion 16. 

For acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML) diagnosis, the blast cell count should be ≥20% in the peripheral blood or bone marrow

Other options:

Option A- Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) arises from immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells called lymphoblasts. Immunohistochemistry for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is positive in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts. Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts that have condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli, and smaller amounts of cytoplasm which lacks granules as shown below.

Option B- Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia is associated with the deletions of 13q, 11q, 17q, and trisomy 12q. Lymph nodes are diffusely effaced by small lymphocytes with proliferation centres. The image shows small round lymphocytes and smudge cells seen in CLL.

Option D- Chronic myeloid leukemia is characterised by the presence of a Philadelphia chromosome resulting from reciprocal translocation t(9;22) forming the BCR-ABL fusion gene. They have a hypercellular marrow due to a massively increased number of maturing granulocytic precursors. The image below shows peripheral smear findings of CML with neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band cells.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia

The WHO system divides acute myeloid leukemia (AML) into several groups:

AML with certain genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes)

  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 8 and 21 [t(8;21)]
  • AML with a translocation or inversion in chromosome 16 [t(16;16) or inv(16)]
  • APL with the PML-RARA fusion gene
  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 11 [t(9;11)]
  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 6 and 9 [t(6:9)]
  • AML with a translocation or inversion in chromosome 3 [t(3;3) or inv(3)]
  • AML (megakaryoblastic) with a translocation between chromosomes 1 and 22 [t(1:22)]
  • AML with the BCR-ABL1 (BCR-ABL) fusion gene*
  • AML with mutated NPM1 gene
  • AML with biallelic mutations of the CEBPA gene (that is, mutations in both copies of the gene)
  • AML with mutated RUNX1 gene*

*This is still a "provisional entity," meaning it is not yet clear if there's enough evidence that it is a unique group.

AML with myelodysplasia-related changes

AML related to previous chemotherapy or radiation

AML not otherwise specified (This includes cases of AML that do not fall into one of the above groups and is similar to the FAB classification.)

  • AML with minimal differentiation (FAB M0)
  • AML without maturation (FAB M1)
  • AML with maturation (FAB M2)
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukemia (FAB M4)
  • Acute monoblastic/monocytic leukemia (FAB M5)
  • Pure erythroid leukemia (FAB M6)
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (FAB M7)
  • Acute basophilic leukemia
  • Acute panmyelosis with fibrosis

Myeloid sarcoma (also known as granulocytic sarcoma or chloroma)

Myeloid proliferations related to Down syndrome

Undifferentiated and biphenotypic acute leukemias are not strictly AML, but are leukemias that have both lymphocytic and myeloid features. They are sometimes called mixed phenotype acute leukemias (MPALs).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of large bowel diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Large bowel diarrhoea is not associated with steatorrhea as fats are absorbed well if the ileum i.e small bowel is functionally intact.

Features Small bowel Large bowel
Volume of stools Large Small
Frequency of stool No change Increased
Blood and mucus in stools Absent Present
Tenesmus Absent Present
Steatorrhea Present Absent
Vomiting May be present Infrequent

Tenesmus refers to the constant urge to defecate with little or no stool passed.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented to the clinic with a history suggestive of a transient ischemic attack 5 hours ago. Which of the following can be used to determine the risk for future stroke?
questions.solution:
The risk of stroke following transient ischemic attacks (TIA) is determined by the ABCD2 score.

TIA is a temporary, focal neurological deficit of sudden onset (stroke-like symptoms) lasting for less than 24 hours.

This occurs due to focal ischemia of the brain, retina, or cochlea. There is a high risk of developing an ischemic stroke after a TIA, especially for the first 3 months following a TIA. 

The components of the ABCD2 are shown in the table below

Age ≥60 years 1 point
<60 years 0 points
Blood pressure elevation when first assessed after TIA Systolic ≥ 140 mm Hg or Diastolic ≥90 mm Hg 1 point
Systolic <140 mm Hg and diastolic < 90 mm Hg 0 points
Clinical features Unilateral weakness 2 points
Isolated speech disturbance 1 point
Other  0 points
Duration of TIA symptoms   ≥60 minutes 2 points
10 to 59 minutes 1 point
<10 minutes 0 points
 Diabetes Present 1 point
Absent  0 points

 Interpretation of ABCD2 score:

  • Score 6 to 7: High two-day stroke risk
  • Score 4 to 5: Moderate two-day stroke risk
  • Score 0 to 3: Low two-day stroke risk

Other options:

Options B and C: BISAP (bedside index of severity in a/c pancreatitis) and APACHE II are used for assessing the severity of Acute pancreatitis.

Option D: CHADS2 score determines the risk of stroke in Atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: Identify the type of amputation given below.
questions.solution:
The given image is of Krukenberg's amputation.

In this procedure, the radius and ulna are split to make a pincer mechanism. It has been recommended in blind patients with bilateral below-elbow amputation or in patients who can't afford expensive prosthesis (to provide some amount of function).

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows the caudal regression sequence/sacral agenesis. The maternal condition that can give rise to this condition in the baby is pregestational diabetes. It is the most specific anomaly seen in diabetes.

Poorly controlled diabetes, both preconceptionally and in early pregnancy, is thought to cause this malformation. HbA1c levels correlate with the malformations. Instead, a macrosomic infant is commonly seen in gestational diabetes.

Other options:

Option B- In gestational diabetes, the risk of fetal anomalies is not increased. This is due to the absence of metabolic disturbance during organogenesis

Option C- Valproate leads to neural tube defects and not sacral agenesis.

Option D- ACE inhibitors can cause oligohydramnios.

questions.text: What is the cause of lactational amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
The cause of lactational amenorrhea is increased prolactin secretion as a result of the baby sucking at the mother's breast.

Lactational amenorrhea:

  • Type of secondary amenorrhea due to the effect of prolactin secretion.
  • During lactation, there are pulsatile bursts of prolactin secretion in response to suckling.
  • Prolactin suppresses GnRH, LH, and FSH causing lactational amenorrhea.
  • Regular lactation with one feed at night delays ovulation and pregnancy for up to 6 months, provided she remains amenorrhoeic.
  • After 6 months, lactation has no bearing on ovulation and pregnancy can occur, despite amenorrhoea and might need other forms of contraception.

questions.text:
A patient following a road traffic accident presented with subcutaneous emphysema. On auscultation, there was no air entry on the right side. Vitals were unstable. What will be your immediate management?

e-FAST- Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma

choices.text: Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)
Wide bore needle decompression and IV fluids

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of no air entry on the right side with a history of road traffic accident and unstable vitals are suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The immediate management is the insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line. This procedure is known as needle decompression or needle thoracostomy. 

Tension pneumothorax is a surgical emergency and the excessive pressure has to be immediately relieved. Tension pneumothorax is managed by immediate needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space (ICS), followed by definitive management with a chest tube inserted in the same space.

A tension pneumothorax develops when there is a tear is either in the parietal or visceral pleura. This tear acts as a one-way valve i.e. air enters from the lung or chest wall through it during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration. This ultimately leads to the collapse of the affected lung.

It is characterized by chest pain, tachypnoea, tachycardia, hypotension, tracheal deviation away from the side of injury, absence of breath sounds on the affected side, and neck vein distention. A patient can develop subcutaneous emphysema as a complication, secondary to the pneumothorax. 

Other options:

Option B: While IV fluids are a part of the resuscitation protocol, hypotension in a tension pneumothorax is due to an obstructive type of shock, increasing circulating volume will have minimal effect on improving blood pressure. The management of the primary cause, tension pneumothorax, takes higher precedence as the next immediate step.

Option C: Intubation is performed when the patient is unresponsive post chest tube insertion. 

Option D: Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (eFAST) is not required before emergency decompression as tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, but it can be performed following chest tube insertion.

questions.text: During psychotherapy, the therapist had mixed conscious and unconscious feelings towards his patient. This is known as_____.
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the therapist has mixed conscious and unconscious feelings towards his patient. This is known as counter-transference.

Counter-transference is the positive and negative feelings/emotions expressed by healthcare professionals towards their patients. It is the process of the physician unconsciously displacing onto the patient patterns of behaviors or emotional reactions as if he/she were a significant figure from earlier in the physician's life. Psychiatrists should be alert to signs of countertransference issues like missed appointments by the psychiatrist, boredom, or sleepiness during a session. Supervision and personal therapy can help the psychiatrist recognize and deal with these issues. 

Transference is the positive and negative feelings expressed by the patients towards the healthcare professional. It is the process of the patient unconsciously displacing onto individuals patterns of behavior and emotional reactions that originated with significant figures from the past (generally in childhood). This displacement is onto the psychiatrist in a clinical scenario, who is a parent surrogate. The patient may be angry, hostile, demanding, or obedient to an extreme degree because of former relationships and patterns of behaviors. Failure to recognize this can make the psychiatrist react to the patient's behavior like a personal attack.

These are not defense mechanisms but are commonly encountered during clinical practice or while giving psychotherapy. In an interview, transference and counter-transference are very significant expressions of unconscious processes.

Option C: Dissociation is an immature defense mechanism. In this, involuntary splitting/suppression of mental functions occurs from the rest of the personality in a way that allows the expression of forbidden unconscious impulses without having a sense of responsibility for actions.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the ER with colicky abdominal pain. His mother tells you that he refuses to walk due to knee pain. On examination, palpable purpura is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of palpable purpura, colicky abdominal pain, and arthritis, point towards a diagnosis of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP) also known as IgA vasculitis.

It is a small vessel vasculitis that occurs due to IgA immune complex deposition within the wall of the blood vessels. It is commonly seen in children and is characterized by:

  • Palpable purpura without thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy.
  • Arthralgia- commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints.
  • Abdominal pain
  • Glomerulonephritis: proteinuria, microscopic hematuria, RBC casts in urine.

The skin biopsy will show small vessel vasculitis, with IgA and C3 deposition in the affected organs by immunofluorescence.

Option B: Hemolytic uremic syndrome is characterized by a triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.

Option C: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is characterized by fever of at least 2 weeks duration associated with arthritis, evanescent erythematous rash, hepatosplenomegaly, generalized lymphadenopathy, and serositis.

Option D: Patients with IgA nephropathy or Berger's disease present with gross hematuria, often associated with a preceding or ongoing viral infection of the upper respiratory tract (synpharyngitic presentation).

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a gradual loss of visual acuity in the left eye. Her MRI head is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and MRI showing tram track sign is suggestive of optic nerve meningioma.

Primary optic nerve meningioma arises from the arachnoid sheath of the optic nerve. CT or MRI shows tram track sign. It is defined as the relative hypoattenuation of the optic nerve on CT or reduced signal on post-gadolinium MRI due to peripheral enhancement of the tumor around the nerve.

 

*Note - Tram track sign refers to the appearance of parallel line lesions and is seen in the following conditions:

  • Tram track sign in the brain is suggestive of Sturge-Weber syndrome
  • Tram track sign in the orbit is suggestive of optic nerve meningioma
  • Tram track sign on microscopy in nephrology is suggestive of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Tram track sign in pulmonology is seen in bronchiectasis

questions.text: Which of the following is false according to Caldwell and Moloy classification of pelvis:

choices.text: Platypelloid pelvis: has AP diameter > transverse diameter
Gynecoid pelvis:  sacral angle greater than 90 degree
Anthropoid pelvis: high incidence of face to pubis delivery

questions.solution:
Platypelloid pelvis has a transverse diameter much larger than the anteroposterior diameter.

  Gynecoid  Anthropoid  Android  Platypelloid 
Shape  Round  Anteroposteriorlyoval  Triangular/ Heart shaped  Transversely oval /Flat bowl 
Sacrum  Sacral angle (SA)more than 90°  SA more than 90° Sacral angle lessthan 90° SA more than 90°
Sidewalls  Straight or slightlydivergent  Straight or divergent  Convergent  Divergent 
Ischial spines  Not prominent  Not prominent  Prominent  Not prominent 
Subpubic angle   Wide (85°)  Slightly narrow  Narrow  Very wide (morethan 90°) 
Position  Occipitolateral or oblique occipitoanterior  Direct occipitoanteriororposterior  Occipitolateral oroblique occipitoposterior  Occipitolateral 
Diameter of engagement  Transverse oroblique  Anteroposterior  Transverse oroblique  Transverse 
Delivery  No difficulty   More incidenceof face-to-pubisdelivery  a/w deep transverse arrest.Difficult delivery with increased chance of perineal injuries  No difficulty

questions.text: Two brothers were arguing over ancestral property when the elder of the two suddenly complained of chest pain. He was brought to the hospital. His family members reported that he was previously healthy and that there were no similar diseases in the family members. Echocardiography was done; the image below shows the findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden chest pain in a previously healthy man under a stressful situation is suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is also called broken heart syndrome, apical ballooning syndrome, or stress-induced cardiomyopathy. It is characterized by a transient myocardial stunning from microcirculation spams due to a catecholamine surge during stress. It is usually seen in middle-aged women. The patients may present with pulmonary edema, hypotension, and chest pain.

Echocardiography reveals apical dilatation with basal hypercontraction of the heart, resembling a takotsubo (pot for catching octopus). The ECG changes can mimic those of myocardial infarction. Therefore, coronary angiography may be needed to rule out coronary occlusion. 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is a self-limiting disorder, resolving within days to weeks. The prognosis is generally good.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents in December with the following lesion on the extensor aspect of the elbow. The lesions are associated with itching. He consumes alcohol and smokes around 9 cigarettes every day. When the doctor scratched the lesions, the scales initially increased. On successive removal of the scales, there was a glossy red membrane. On removal of the membrane, there were pinpoint bleeding spots. He says that similar lesions are also present on the trunk. All other features mentioned below can be found in this patient except
questions.solution:
The given image shows red scaly plaque with silvery-white fine scales, and the lesion on scratching shows Auspitz's sign on scratching. These features are suggestive of psoriasis in the patient. Pautrier's microabscess is a feature of mycosis fungoides.

Psoriasis is a chronic, inflammatory and proliferative condition of the skin that also involves various organ manifestations. 

Several factors play a role in the development of the disease. They can be streptococcal infections, medications like beta-blockers, non‐steroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and angiotensin‐converting enzymes, alcohol abuse, cigarette smoking, and psychological stress.

Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis and is seen in 80-90% of patients. The peak on occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash. The lesions are red, scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin. They can also be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring. They commonly appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

When the lesions are scratched, the scaling increases initially. The successive removal of scales usually reveals an underlying smooth, glossy red membrane. This membrane when removed shows small bleeding points. This finding is called Auspitz’s sign.

The nails may be involved in psoriasis. The nails grow quickly in patients with psoriasis. Involvement of nail matrix disease leads to pits, ridges, and grooves of the nail plate. Involvement of nail bed causes subungual oil drops, subungual hyperkeratosis, and distal onycholysis.

Histopathology will show the presence of hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, the disappearance of the granular layer, and epidermal hyperplasia. In the Malpighian layer, neutrophils may accumulate to form the characteristic spongiform pustules of Kogoj. Accumulation of neutrophils in the stratum corneum forms Munro microabscess. There is hyperplasia and elongation of rete ridges with dilated and tortuous blood vessels. 

Image: Silvery white scales on the extensor aspect of elbow seen in psoriasis

Related Pearl: Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

I. In Mild Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • Coal tar
  • Dithranol
  • Potent topical steroid
  • Vitamin D analogue

Second line

  • Local NB-UVB or PUVA
  • Excimer laser

II. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • NB-UVB or PUVA

Second line

  • Acitretin
  • Apremilast
  • Ciclosporin
  • Fumaric acid esters (where available)
  • Methotrexate

Third line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Secukinumab
  • Ustekinumab

III. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis with Psoriatic Arthritis

First line

  • Apremilast
  • Methotrexate

Second line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Ustekinumab

Third line

  • Combination therapy

questions.text: Identify the fingerprint pattern shown below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a fingerprint with loops. These are the most common fingerprint patterns. 

Patterns of fingerprints:

  • Loops - These constitute 60-70% of patterns encountered. 
  • Whorl - Represent 25-30% of patterns encountered.
  • Arch - Represent about 5% of patterns encountered. They may be plain, tented, or exceptional.

questions.text: As a first-year surgery resident, you have scrubbed in to assist a urologist on a TURP procedure. Up to what distal anatomical landmark do you expect him to resect?
questions.solution:
Verumontanum is used as the distal-most border of the resection in transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). This prevents damage to the external urethral sphincter which is located just distal to the verumontanum.

Damage to the external urethral sphincter leads to urinary incontinence.

The bladder neck is the proximal limit of resection.

questions.text: Dimercaprol is indicated as an antidote in patients with which of the following poisoning?
questions.solution:
Dimercaprol (BAL) is an antidote for gold, arsenic (except arsine), or acute mercury poisoning (except non-alkyl mercury). It is also an adjunct to edetate calcium disodium in acute lead poisoning.

Dimercaprol has also been approved by the FDA to treat Wilson's disease but not acute copper poisoning. The use of dimercaprol in the management of poisoning for other heavy metals has not been validated.

Note: Mnemonic: B.A.L. for M.A.L. (Mercury, arsenic, and lead).

questions.text: Identify the following deformity seen in a patient complaining of pain and swelling of her hands.
questions.solution:
The image is showing flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint is suggestive of Boutonnière deformity seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes are nodules in osteoarthritis that are palpable in the distal interphalangeal joint and proximal interphalangeal joints respectively. 

Hitchhiker thumb deformity is a musculoskeletal manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis. It is seen on the thumb. The deformity has flexion at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint hyperextension at the interphalangeal (IP) joint

 

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Subluxation of the 1st MCP joint with hyperextension of the 1st IP joint. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: Rosemont criteria for diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis is based on_____
questions.solution:
Rosemont’s criteria for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis is based on endoscopic ultrasonographic (EUS) findings.

questions.text: A 29-year-old presented with purple, pruritic plaques on the flexor aspect of the left forearm for 7 months. On examination, Koebner's phenomenon was elicited. A skin biopsy showed Civatte bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with symptoms of purple, itchy, plaque exhibiting Koebner's phenomenon is suggestive of lichen planus. It is characterized by the presence of Civatte bodies or colloid bodies.

The colloid body is a homogeneous, eosinophilic, rounded body resulting from the degeneration and death of keratinocytes, particularly in the lower layers of the epidermis. This structure is found in various lichenoid tissue reactions.

Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membrane. Microscopy will show :

  • Acanthosis of the epidermis.
  • Irregular thickening of the granular layer.
  • Hyperkeratosis.
  • Colloid (civatte) bodies due to degenerating basal epidermal cells. 
  • Sawtooth appearance of rete ridges.
  • Max Joseph spaces due to focal separation from the dermis.
  • Band‐like infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes near the dermo-epidermal junction.

Patients present with pruritic, purple, polygonal, papules. The lesions have thin white lines on their surface known as Wickham’s striae (seen below). They are commonly seen on the volar aspect of the wrists, the lumbar region, and around the ankles.

The mucosal involvement is also seen. The commonest mucosal sites are buccal mucosa and tongue, rarely it can also be found on the anus and genitalia. 

Option A: Copper penny bodies are seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Option C: Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale.

Option D: Kamino bodies are eosinophilic globules seen in the epidermis or in the region of the dermal-epidermal junction in the spindle and epithelioid cell (Spitz) naevi.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum

Psoriasis

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.
