questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the OPD with a skin lesion as shown in the image below. The lesions were initially small but have now spread to the entire limb and the abdomen. She has a history of long-standing diabetes and recurrent episodes of deep vein thrombosis despite anticoagulation therapy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image depicts necrolytic migratory erythema. This skin lesion along with a history of long-standing diabetes and recurrent deep vein thrombosis is suggestive of glucagonoma. Necrolytic migratory erythema is commonly associated with glucagon secreting pancreatic islet cell adenoma.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of glucaganoma: 4Ds

  • Diabetes – usually mild and not associated with ketoacidosis
  • Dermatitis – Necrolytic erythema migrans
  • Deep vein thrombosis
  • Depression

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Syndrome

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms
  • Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.
  • In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of ectopic parathyroid gland?
questions.solution:
The most common site of the ectopic parathyroid gland is paraesophageal.

The common sites of ectopic parathyroid glands are

  • Paraesophageal - most common
  • Mediastinal 
  • Intrathymic 
  • Intrathyroidal 
  • Carotid sheath 
  • High cervical or undescended 

Ectopic parathyroid is the most common cause of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism. In such cases, treatment involves surgical removal of the gland.

questions.text: A mother brings her 9-year-old child with complaints of polyuria. On examination, he has growth failure and bitemporal hemianopia. Laboratory evaluation reveals low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality. Findings on the MRI brain are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the MRI showing intracranial mass with foci of calcification at sella turcica and the laboratory findings suggestive of diabetes insipidus point to a diagnosis of craniopharyngioma.

Craniopharyngiomas are tumors that arise from the remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is an intracranial space-occupying lesion. It has bimodal age of presentation. Children usually present with frequent headaches, short stature, bitemporal hemianopsia (due to optic chiasm compression), and polyuria.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick brownish-yellow fluid and are compared to machine oil. They also show radiologically demonstrable calcification.

Diabetes insipidus in these patients can be diagnosed with features such as polyuria, low urine osmolality, and high plasma osmolality. Treatment of central diabetes insipidus caused by craniopharyngioma includes supplementation with vasopressin analogs such as desmopressin (DDAVP) and resection of the tumor.

Other options:

Option B: Germinomas of the pituitary stalk also cause central diabetes insipidus. However, they are often missed in routine neuroimaging. 

Option C: Pituitary microadenomas usually present incidentally or with endocrine effects. They are <10mm in size and the tumor is confined to the sella. Visual field deficits are usually caused by pituitary macroadenomas. 

Option D: Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare cause of central diabetes insipidus. Symptoms include dermatological manifestations such as red, scaly papules, pain, and swelling in the limbs, characteristic bony lesions, and disseminated lymph node enlargement.

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

Acquired

  • Head trauma (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery
  • Neoplasms
  • Granulomas
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Histiocytosis
  • Infectious
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Inflammatory
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  • Vascular
    • Sheehan’s syndrome
    • Aneurysm (internal carotid)

Congenital

  • Malformations
  • Genetic
    • Wolfram syndrome

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presented with a 1.5cm pigmented lesion on the face which is growing rapidly in size and associated with itching. The lesion is shown below. Which of the following is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 1cm pigmented lesion on the face which is asymmetrical, with an irregular border, made of black and brown pigments, and increasing rapidly in size, points towards a diagnosis of malignant melanoma. 

Types of melanoma:

  • Lentigo maligna
  • Superficial spreading
  • Acral lentiginous
  • Nodular

Histopathology of melanoma:

  • Individual melanoma cells are larger than normal melanocytes
  • They have large nuclei with irregular contours, chromatin is characteristically clumped at the periphery of the nuclear membrane with prominent red eosinophilic nucleoli
  • All tumors have a vertical and radial phase of growth. The appearance of melanocytes is similar in both phases. The vertical growth has is often heralded by the appearance of a nodule.
  • The possibility of metastasis correlates with the depth of invasion which is called the Breslow thickness.

 

Type Clinical features Spread
Basal cell carcinoma

Nodule

Central ulceration with a pearly surface,

telangiectasia

 local
Squamous cell carcinoma

Ulcer with thickened margins, keratosis

Papillomatous

Local,

lymph nodes
Malignant melanoma

>6 mm pigmented, 

vascularization

inflammation

Local

vascular

lymph nodes

Other options:

Option A: A dysplastic nevus is formed at the dermo-epidermal junction. They are usually smaller in size than melanoma, have a fuzzy border, and are more likely to show brown-tan pigmentation. Any blue-black pigmentation should raise suspicion of melanoma. The majority of them regress on their own.

Option B: Congenital melanocytic nevus may be small, medium or large size(>20cm). A large-sized mole may show an atypical network and have a risk of melanoma growth. But a history of being present since birth or infancy needs to be present.

 Option C: Acquired melanocytic nevus (common mole) is rarely more than 1cm in size. It also does not show atypical network

questions.text: A patient presents with hip pain and apparent lengthening of the limb which was diagnosed as tuberculosis of the hip. Which stage of the disease is he currently in?
questions.solution:
In a patient with tuberculosis of the hip, apparent lengthening of the limb is seen in stage I which is known as the stage of synovitis.

Clinical features seen in the stages of TB hip are:

  • The stage of synovitis presents with apparent lengthening of the limb.
  • The stage of arthritis presents with apparent shortening of the limb.
  • The stage of erosion presents with true shortening of the limb.

Note: The apparent length of the limb is measured from the xiphisternum to the medial malleolus. The true length of the limb is measured from the anterior superior iliac spine to the medial malleolus.

questions.text: A female patient presents with numbness in her fingertips. On examination, her face appears tightened. The antinuclear antibody(ANA) is found to be positive and immunofluorescence demonstrates a nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Numbness of fingers (associated with Raynaud's phenomenon), facial tightening, and positive anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) with nucleolar pattern in immunofluorescence are highly suggestive of systemic sclerosis.

Systemic sclerosis/ scleroderma:

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune connective tissue disorder that results in fibrosis of the skin, vasculature, and internal organs. It is of two types, namely diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis and limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. 

Scleroderma is characterized by Raynaud's phenomenon, digital ischemia, sclerodactyly, calcinosis, telangiectasia, and cardiac, lung, gastrointestinal and renal disease. Skin thickening is the hallmark of SSc. Patients have a characteristic expressionless facial appearance with taut and shiny skin and microstomia.

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are positive in SSC. The presence of anti-topoisomerase 1 (Scl70) and anticentromere antibodies are seen in diffuse cutaneous SSC and limited cutaneous SSc respectively.

The nucleolar pattern of ANA staining in immunofluorescence is most commonly seen in systemic sclerosis. A centromeric pattern is also seen.

The image below shows the nucleolar pattern in immunofluorescence seen in systemic sclerosis.

Other options:

Option B: Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disease characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of salivary and lacrimal glands. 

Patients present with dry eye (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia) due to fibrosis of the lacrimal and salivary gland respectively.

Anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies are positive in Sjogren's syndrome. ANA and RF (Rheumatoid factor) can also be seen. Centromeric patterns and speckled patterns of staining are seen in Sjogren's syndrome.

The image below shows a speckled pattern of staining.

Option C: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that most commonly presents with arthralgia with early morning stiffness. 

Other important features of SLE include malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, pleuritis, pericarditis, and lupus nephritis.

ANA, Anti-dsDNA antibodies, anti-smith antibodies are positive in SLE. Homogenous or diffuse staining and peripheral staining pattern are most commonly seen in SLE.

Image below shows a homogenous or diffuse stained immunofluorescence pattern seen in SLE.

Option D: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a multisystem disease that classically presents with pain, joint swelling, and stiffness of the small joints of the hands, feet, and wrists in a symmetrical manner.

RF and anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies are positive in RA. Homogenous staining is the most common pattern seen in RA.

Related Pearl: Manifestations of systemic sclerosis

Organ

Manifestations

Skin

Endothelial injury and microvascular disease causing chronic ischemia

Alimentary Tract

Affected in approximately 90% of patients.

Progressive atrophy and collagenous fibrous replacement of the muscular is most severe in the esophagus.

The lower two-thirds of the esophagus often develops a rubber-hose–like an inflexibility.

Gastroesophageal reflux and Barrett metaplasia and strictures.

Musculoskeletal System

Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the synovial soft tissues

Joint destruction is not common in systemic sclerosis.

Inflammatory myositis

Kidneys.

The most prominent are the vascular lesions.

Interlobular arteries show intimal thickening as a result of deposition of mucinous or finely collagenous material

Lungs.

The lungs are involved in more than 50% of individuals

Pulmonary hypertension and interstitial fibrosis

Pulmonary fibrosis

Heart

Pericarditis with effusion, myocardial fibrosis, and thickening of intramyocardial arterioles

questions.text: In lymphedema, skin on the base of the toes cannot be pinched due to subcutaneous fibrosis. This sign is called?
questions.solution:
In Lymphedema, skin on the base of the toes cannot be pinched due to subcutaneous fibrosis. This sign is called Stemmer’s sign.

Sign Description
Stemmer's sign
  • Seen in Lymphoderma
  • Skin on the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched due to Subcutaneous Fibrosis.
Frank's sign
  • A diagonal crease in the earlobe that runs backward from the tragus at a 45-degree angle across the lobule to the rear edge of the auricle.
  • May be  a predictor of Coronary Artery disease.
Levine's sign
  • Clenched fist held over the chest to describe Ischemic Chest Pain.
Winterbottom's sign
  • Posterior Cervical Lymphadenopathy in African Trypanosomiasis.

questions.text:
A middle-aged woman presents with heat intolerance and fine tremors in both her hands for 6 months. She also complains of palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities. Examination revealed a BP of 136/86 mm Hg, tachycardia, and exophthalmos. Which of the statements is true in this patient?

RAIU - Radioactive Iodine Uptake

choices.text: RAIU at 24 hours is below normal

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient's symptoms point toward hyperthyroidism, and eye findings like exophthalmos are highly suggestive of Graves' disease. In this condition, the serum TSH is low, unbound T4 is high, and T3 is high. 

Graves disease is an autoimmune disease with a strong familial predisposition (50%) and females are at a higher risk with a peak incidence between the ages of 40-60 years. The most common cause of hyperthyroidism is due to stimulatory autoantibodies i.e Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) to TSH-R. Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) binds to and activates the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor resulting in diffuse toxic goiter and therefore, increased T4 and T3 levels. The clinical features include:

Symptoms:

  • Hyperactivity,  irritability, dysphoria
  • Heat intolerance and sweating
  • Palpitations
  • Fatigue and weakness
  • Weight loss with increased appetite
  • Diarrhea
  • Polyuria
  • Oligomenorrhea,  loss of libido

Signs:

  • Tachycardia, atrial fibrillation in the elderly
  • Tremor
  • Goiter
  • Warm, moist skin
  • Muscle weakness, proximal myopathy
  • Lid retraction or lag
  • Gynecomastia
  • Extra thyroidal conditions include ophthalmopathy, dermopathy (pretibial myxedema), thyroid acropachy, gynecomastia, and other manifestations.

Diagnosis:

  • Lab Investigations:
    • T4 and T3 increased due to the stimulating effect of TSI on the TSH receptors.
    • TSH is reduced as increased T4 levels in the blood lead to negative feedback on TRH in the hypothalamus.
    • Elevated TSH-R antibodies- diagnostic
    • Anti-Tg and anti-TPO are seen but nonspecific
  • Radiological investigations:
    • RAIU (radioactive iodine uptake) at 24 hours is characteristically above normal due to increased thyroid hormone production.

questions.text: What is the maneuver being performed in the given image?
questions.solution:
The maneuver being performed in the given image is that of head-tilt chin-lift. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.

Basic life support involves early recognition and management of emergencies such as heart attack, stroke, and foreign body airway obstruction. The sequence of BLS is circulation (chest compression), airway, and then breathing.

The airway is usually obstructed by posterior displacement of the tongue or epiglottis. One hand (palm) is placed on the patient’s forehead applying pressure to tilt the head back. Simultaneously, the chin is lifted with the forefinger and index finger of the opposite hand. This causes cervical flexion with an atlantooccipital extension (sniffing position). This lifts the tongue from the back of the throat.

Head-tilt chin-lift should not be performed in a patient with suspected cervical injury.

Other options: 

Option B: Jaw thrust- Both hands of the clinician are placed on either side of the patient’s head and the angles of the jaw are grasped and lifted. It can be performed in a patient with cervical injury but caution must be followed to not hyperextend the neck.

 

Option D: Manual inline stabilization is a maneuver that limits external head and neck movement in patients with cervical spine injuries. Fingers and palms of both hands are used to stabilize the patient's occiput and mastoid processes to ensure successful airway intervention.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

questions.text: Which of the following features aids in differentiating a true bruise from an artificial bruise?

choices.text: Progression of the color of bruise over time

questions.solution:
One of the features of differentiation of a true bruise from an artificial bruise is the progression of the color of the bruise over time. 

Other options: 

Options A, C, and D: Positive chemical tests, regular and well-defined margins, and the presence of vesicles are features of an artificial bruise. 

Artificial bruises are caused by the application of certain irritant substances such as the juice of marking nut, calotropis, or plumbago rosea to simulate true bruises.

The following features can be used to distinguish between the two categories.

Trait Artificial bruise True bruise
Site Accessible parts Anywhere
Color Dark brown Typical color progression over time
Shape Irregular Rounded
Margins Well defined and regular Ill-defined and irregular
Vesicles Present Absent
Redness/ Inflammation Present in the surrounding skin Present over bruise
Itching Present Absent
Chemical tests Positive Negative

questions.text: A 35-year-old man files a case against a surgeon who left a cotton swab inside his abdomen after a hernia repair. Which of the following best describes this scenario of medical negligence?
questions.solution:
Res ipsa loquitur best describes this scenario under medical negligence.

Res ipsa loquitur means the facts of the case speak for themselves.

Normally, in cases of medical negligence, the burden of proof lies on the patient to prove the doctor guilty. However, the patient need not prove any negligence under Res ipsa loquitur.

The conditions to be fulfilled for Res Ipsa Loquitur are:

  • The injury or damage would not have occurred without negligence
  • The doctor is in exclusive control of the instrumentation or circumstances
  • The patient must not contribute to his own injury or damage

Several situations can be used as defenses by the doctor against medical negligence. This includes no duty owed to the plaintiff/ patient, the doctor's duty has been discharged according to prevailing standards, a scenario of misadventure that may be therapeutic, diagnostic, and experimental, or an error of judgment.

Other options:

Option A: Res judicata under section 300 Cr. P.C states that if a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question.

Option C: Limitation or Res indicata indicates that a suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed. But, where a breach of duty to provide care as per a particular contract between a patient and a doctor is committed, legal action can be initiated up to three years from the date of alleged negligence.

Option D: Novus Actus Interveniens is a situation where the cause of disability or death passes from the doctor to a later negligent action of some other person. It means a person is responsible not only for his actions but also for the logical consequences of those actions. For a plea of Novus actus, an element of negligence is absolutely essential.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with history of ovarian carcinoma in the mother achieved menopause with smooth transition. And she is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain and on examination the right adnexal mass was palpable, non tender. On USG examination she has a 3 X 3 cm smooth cyst in her ovary. Which is the next step

choices.text: Reassure and advise regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirm USG findings by ordering CT scan
Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualise the nature of cyst
Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

questions.solution:
Doing a CA-125 level measurement is the next best step according to the latest RCOG guidelines for Post-menopausal Ovarian cyst.

Initial steps in management include the following:

  • Estimate CA – 125 level
  • USG
  • Calculating Risk of Malignancy index
    • RMI = U x  M  x  Ca-125
    • U – Ultrasound score
    • M – Menopausal status
    • Ca 125 – Serum levels

Option B - CT scan is not recommended in initial evaluation.

Option C - Laparotomy/laparoscopy only indicated if size > 5 cm or RMI > 200.

questions.text: The chest radiograph of a patient in the ICU revealed a wedge-shaped opacity as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is pulmonary embolism. The plain radiograph in the vignette demonstrates Hampton's hump which is a chest radiograph finding in patients with pulmonary embolism.

Hampton's hump is a wedge-shaped opacification beside the pleural surface. This is representative of a pulmonary infarction distal to a pulmonary embolus.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign- Area of focal oligemia

Chest radiograph reveals an engorged pulmonary trunk with an abrupt cutoff of pulmonary vascularity in the distal portions bilaterally, indicative of the "Westermark sign" (arrows).

 

 

 

Hampton's hump- A peripheral wedged-shaped density above the diaphragm with convexity towards hilum.

 

 

 

 

Palla's sign- enlarged right descending pulmonary artery

Chest x-ray on a PA projection that shows focal relative oligemia of the right upper lung (Westermark's sign, circle), in contrast to significantly dilated right descending pulmonary artery, with a “sausage-like” appearance (Palla's sign, arrow)

 

 

 

Remember- A normal or nearly normal chest x-ray often occurs in PE.

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV patient presented with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. His sputum sample showed acid-fast bacilli. What is the appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Start ART and then ATT after 2 weeks
Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks

questions.solution:
In a patient with HIV and TB start ATT first and then start ART as soon as ATT is tolerated (between 2 weeks and 2 months) by the patient. This is done in order to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). 

Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS):

Patients with HIV-related TB may experience a temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting ATT. This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to the simultaneous administration of ART and ATT.

It is characterized by high fever, lymphadenopathy, expanding intra-thoracic lesions, and worsening of chest X-ray findings. Diagnosis should be made only after ruling out treatment failure and other infections. For severe cases, prednisone 1-2mg/kg is used for 1-2 weeks and then gradually tapered.

However, in patients with CD4 <50/μL, the benefits of administering ART immediately after initiating ATT outweigh the risks of IRIS, and therefore ART should be started as early as possible.

World HIV day is observed annually on 1st December. This year’s theme is “Putting Ourselves to the Test: Achieving Equity to End HIV.” It encourages people to unite globally to eliminate the disparities and inequities that create barriers to HIV testing, prevention, and access to HIV care

questions.text: A concerned mother presents to the outpatient department with complaints of reddish vaginal discharge after 3 days of delivery. Her vitals were stable and there were no associated signs of sepsis. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lochia rubra.

Lochia is a type of vaginal discharge seen in the first fortnight during puerperium. Depending on the color it is named as:

  • Lochia rubra is red in color and seen during the first 1-4 days.
  • Lochia serosa is yellowish or pale brownish and seen during the initial 5-9 days.
  • Lochia alba is pale white in appearance and is seen 10-15 days postpartum.

questions.text: Which intravenous anesthetic has the maximum incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Etomidate has the highest incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) among intravenous anesthetics.

Propofol has antiemetic properties thereby reducing PONV.

Other potential adverse effects of etomidate:

  • Adrenocortical suppression
  • Myoclonus
  • Seizure precipitation
  • Pain on injection

questions.text: During your rural posting, you are asked to educate a small village about the importance of routine antenatal care for pregnant mothers. You want to deliver some statistical data to emphasize its importance. Which of the following is the best method to do so?
questions.solution:
A pictogram is the best method of presenting data to people who cannot understand orthodox charts/ uneducated populations. 

In this method, small pictures or symbols are used to present the data.

The following image shows an example of a pictogram.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: Craniospinal irradiation is used in the treatment of:
questions.solution:
Medulloblastoma is a radiosensitive tumor and responds very well to radiotherapy. 

  • CNS malignancies which show dissemination via CSF: Medulloblastoma, Glioblastoma, Germinoma, Leptomeningeal rhabdomyosarcoma.
  • Radiosensitive tumors which have a high risk of metastasis to CNS: Small cell lung cancer, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

questions.text: A young patient presents to you with the following finding. What is the nerve affected?
questions.solution:
The given image shows is that of a claw hand classically seen in case of an ulnar nerve injury.

The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals, adductor pollicis, interossei, and hypothenar muscles in the hand. The lumbricals are primarily responsible for the extension at the interphalangeal joints. Therefore, in ulnar nerve palsy, there is clawing of the medial two fingers.

In ulnar nerve palsy, only the medial two fingers develop clawing, while in a combined median and ulnar nerve palsy, all four fingers develop clawing. 

The following tests are done to test the integrity of the ulnar nerve:

  • Egawa's test - In a positive test, due to the weakness of the dorsal interossei, side-to-side movements of the middle finger is weak.
  • Book test or Froment's sign - The patient is asked to hold a book between the thumb and index finger while the examiner attempt to pull it forcefully. In case of an ulnar nerve injury, the adductor pollicis is paralyzed and the patient attempts to hold the book with the flexor pollicis longus muscle supplied by the median nerve.
  • Card test - In the case of weak palmar interossei, the examiner can pull out the card with ease. 

Other options

Option B - In radial nerve palsy, the patient presents with a wrist drop due to paralyzed wrist extensors. In high lesions, there is sensory loss on the dorsum of the hand over the anatomical stuff box. 

Option C - In median nerve injury, paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle leads to ape thumb deformity. A pointing finger deformity can also be seen due to paralyzed flexors of the fingers.

Option D - Long thoracic nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle. Patients with injury to this nerve present with winging of the scapula.

questions.text: Chest radiography of a patient revealed the following finding. Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows superior rib notching. Coarctation of aorta is associated with inferior rib notching.

Hyperparathyroidism and neurofibromatosis cause both superior and inferior rib notching.

Causes of superior rib notching are:

  • Normal finding in the elderly
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Marfan's syndrome
  • Paraplegics and poliomyelitis

Causes for inferior rib notching (Roesler sign) are:

  • Unilateral:
    • Subclavian artery occlusion.
    • Coarctation of aorta involving left subclavian or anomalous right subclavian artery
  • Bilateral:
    • Coarctation of aorta, occlusion, aortitis
    • Takayasu’s disease and atheroma of subclavian artery
    • Pulmonary oligemia (ToF, pulmonary atresia, stenosis)
    • SVC or IVC obstruction
    • AV malformation
    • Neurofibromatosis type 1

The image given below shows inferior rib notching.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with limping gait and left hip pain. A plain radiograph of his hip shows the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of limping gait and left hip pain with radiographic findings of the radiolucency and distorted articular surface is suggestive of avascular necrosis. 

Avascular necrosis or osteonecrosis is a painful bone condition as a result of diminished blood supply mainly due to trauma or non-traumatic etiologies. 

The typical features are pain with movements in or near the joint, click in the joint, joint stiffness, limping gait, and deformity. Restriction of movements is also a feature of this condition. The radiograph shows reactive new bone formation, increased radiolucency in the subchondral bone, and a distorted articular surface. 

Management in the early stages can involve osteotomy while in late stages pain control, splinting, arthrodesis, and total or partial replacement are preferred.  

Other options: 

Option A: Tuberculosis of the hip is characterized by painful and restricted movements of the hip. The radiographic findings are not appreciable in the early stages. But late stages show periarticular osteoporosis, hazy, and irregular joint margins with a reduction in the joint space, and wandering acetabulum. 

Option B: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is usually seen in females in the 4th to 5th decade. Patients present with symmetrical polyarthritis of the proximal finger joints, tenosynovitis, early morning stiffness and pain. RA of the hip can be bilateral. Radiographic findings such as joint space narrowing due to hyaline cartilage destruction, cyst formation, and acetabular protrusion type deformity can be seen.

Option C: Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease of the spine and sacroiliac joint. It typically occurs in the age group 15-25 years with a male preponderance. Features include backache, stiffness, sciatica, and fixed flexion contracture. Radiographic findings show erosion of sacroiliac joints, squaring, and bridging of the vertebral body leading to a bamboo spine appearance.

questions.text: During childbirth, a mother sustains an injury to the perineum as shown in the image below. What is the likely grade of this injury?
questions.solution:
The grade of this perineal laceration is Grade 3b. 

A perineal injury occurs due to overstretching or rapid stretching of the perineum during childbirth.

The perineum, perineal muscles, and >50% of the external anal sphincter are injured in Grade 3b perineal tears.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the video below.
questions.solution:
The above illustration shows Lahey's method of thyroid palpation.

Lahey's Method: The lobes are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the lobe laterally by the left hand and the lobe is palpated with the right hand.

Other options:

  • Crile's Method: The patient is asked to swallow while palpating the gland with the thumb, with the gland between the thumb and other fingers.
  • Kocher's Method: it is done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor.
  • Pemberton's sign: Obstruction to the major veins in the thorax causes engorgement of neck veins. This sign becomes obvious when the patients are asked to raise the hands above the head and the arms touch the ears. This is known as Pemberton’s sign.

questions.text: What is the location of the Bartholin cyst?
questions.solution:
Bartholin cysts are located in the posterior 1/3 of the vulva.

The Bartholin glands are known as the greater vestibular glands in females. These glands are located in the posterior part of the vestibule and open through a duct into the vaginal orifice at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. They secrete mucus during sexual arousal for lubrication. They are the homologs of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands.

Bartholin cyst is caused by obstruction of the duct due to infection, trauma, mucus changes, and congenitally narrowed ducts. If the cyst gets infected, it leads to the formation of a Bartholin abscess. Escherichia coli is the most common causative agent, however, other gram-positive and gram-negative organisms can also cause the same.

Clinical features:

  • If the size is big, it might cause abdominal and vaginal discomfort with dyspareunia. 
  • A vulval cleft of 'S' shape is usually noted on inspection.
  • It is fluctuant swelling and transillumination can be positive as the fluid collected is generally clear.

Treatment:

  • Analgesics for pain
  • Antibiotic for combating infections.
  • Specific treatment:
    1. Drainage under anesthesia: Generally conservative method, chances of re-infection and formation of granulation tissue can happen.
    2. Marsupialization Complete excision of sac and cyst along with drainage of the substance. The edges are also clearly approximated. This is the ideal management.  The advantages of marsupialization over other methods include:
      • Simple procedure
      • Can be done even under local anesthesia.
      • Shorter hospital stay (24 hours).
      • The postoperative complication is almost nil.
      • Gland function (moisture) remains intact. 
    3. Incision and drainage with word catheter placement: A deflated word catheter is used to tuck the vagina here and prevent it from damage that can happen during movement of the perineum and thus avert re-infection and granulation tissue formation. Alternatively, a 14 F foley catheter can also be used.
    4. Bartholinectomy: This is a very invasive surgery and carries a greater morbidity profile. This is also associated with loss of lubricant function. 

Notes:

In any woman above the age of forty with recurrent Bartholin cyst, a suspicion of Bartholin gland cancer should arise and the cyst wall should be sent for biopsy.

questions.text: A man presents with pain and swelling of the right knee joint for one week with the following lesions on his soles. He also complains of pain in his ankle and feet for the past 2 days. He gives a history of diarrhea 4 weeks ago.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows keratoderma blennorrhagica. The clinical scenario describes acute arthritis following a recent infection with an additive pattern (involvement of new joints within a few days). These features suggest the diagnosis of reactive arthritis or Reiter's syndrome. 

Reactive arthritis (ReA) is a condition included in the spectrum of seronegative spondyloarthropathies. It is an acute asymmetric nonpurulent oligoarthritis precipitated by an antecedent gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection. It is characterized by a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. It occurs most commonly in the age group 18-40 years and is associated with HLA-B27.

Bacterial triggers for ReA are caused by Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, Chlamydia trachomatis, Clostridium difficile, certain toxigenic Escherichia coli, Ureaplasma urealyticum, and Mycoplasma genitalium.

The clinical features of reactive arthritis include constitutional symptoms like fever, malaise, fatigue, weight loss. Patients develop arthritis which is asymmetric and additive involving large weight-bearing joints like the knee and ankle. Sacroiliitis and spondylitis occur as late sequelae and are more commonly asymmetric. Non-marginal syndesmophytes which are comma-shaped arising from the middle of the vertebral body are seen. Dactylitis or sausage digit and enthesitis are also seen.

Extraarticular manifestation of reactive arthritis:

  • Keratoderma blennorrhagica presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions/crusting on the palms and soles.
  • Oral ulcers: Superficial, transient, and often asymptomatic.
  • Circinate balanitis: consists of vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis.
  • Anterior uveitis
  • Conjunctivitis

Laboratory investigations reveal elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein. Synovial fluid analysis shows inflammatory changes with negative culture. Joint radiograph shows juxta-articular osteoporosis, marginal erosions, loss of joint space, and periostitis with new bone formation.

Treatment includes NSAIDs, intralesional glucocorticoids, and antibiotics during the antecedent infection.

Other options:

Option A: Ankylosing spondylitis commonly involves young male adults. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker. 

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at age <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for >3 months 

Radiographic findings in ankylosing spondylitis:

Sacro-iliac joints show cardinal sign/earliest sign– erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints

Vertebral changes: Earliest change is the flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’). Bamboo spine appearance occurs due to bridging at several vertebral levels.

X-ray showing the characteristic bamboo-spine appearance:

Option B: Psoriatic arthritis is an asymmetrical oligoarthritis. It is associated with nail pitting/ onycholysis, or dactylitis, enthesitis. The inflammation is prominent in the distal interphalangeal joints. There is dactylitis with pronounced telescoping. Nail dystrophy (hyperkeratosis and onycholysis) affects each of the fingers. Axial involvement may occur.

Radiological features:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity of distal interphalangeal joint
  • marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation "whiskering"

X-ray shows 'pencil-in-cup' involving metacarpophalangeal joints:

Option C: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disease. Its incidence increases between 25 and 55 years of age. The patient usually presents with swelling and pain in the small joints of the hands. Metacarpophalangeal(MCP) and proximal interphalangeal(PIP) joints are commonly involved. The patient also has morning stiffness in the affected joints.

questions.text: As a first-year resident assisting in a superficial parotidectomy, you have been asked to identify the facial nerve trunk. All of the following structures can be used for its localization, except ____.
questions.solution:
The inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle is not used as an anatomical landmark for the identification of the facial nerve trunk.

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 

1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. The anatomical landmarks include:

  • Conley's pointer is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Posterior belly of digastric - The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle.
  • Mastoid process - Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.
  • Squamotympanic fissure is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
  • Styloid process - The facial nerve lies superficial to it.

2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches that are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:

  • Buccal branch lies in relation to the parotid gland
  • Marginal mandibular branch lies in relation to the facial vessels
  • Temporal branch

The given image shows the anatomical relations useful for the localization of the facial nerve trunk.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman came with complaints of abdominal pain, shortness of breath, and vomiting for a few hours. She is on ovulation induction therapy for infertility.  Her sonogram of both ovaries is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the sonogram showing enlarged ovaries meeting in the midline having large cysts are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is an iatrogenic complication seen during the luteal phase or early pregnancy. It is seen in patients taking ovulation induction therapies for infertility more common in FSH/LH therapy than clomiphene or pulsatile GnRH therapies. 

The pathogenesis in OHSS is the increased vascular permeability leading to a fluid shift from intravascular to extravascular space.

They often present with shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and gastrointestinal disturbances like nausea, vomiting, and oliguria. Abdominal pain occurs due to ovarian enlargement and accumulation of peritoneal fluid. Increased vascular permeability and loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity cause ascites and result in hemoconcentration. Hemoconcentration causes hyperviscosity and leads to hypercoagulability. Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, leukocytosis, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion can be associated with OHSS. 

This condition can be prevented by

  • Withholding hCG in a cycle if there are more than 20 follicles on ultrasound and E2 level rises to 3000 pg/ mL.
  • Albumin 5% infusion in 500 mL lactated Ringer’s solution during and after oocyte retrieval
  • Dopamine agonist cabergoline 0.5 mg daily for 8 days starting on day 1 of hCG.

OHSS is primarily managed with general supportive care. Paracentesis is performed to ameliorate abdominal discomfort and relieve respiratory discomfort.

Other options:

Option B- Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is the most common endocrine disorder of the reproductive age group. Patients with PCOS present with menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, acne, infertility, etc.

The ultrasound examination image shown below is of PCOS showing enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts. 


Option C- Hyperreactio luteinalis is a condition in which one or both ovaries develop multiple large theca lutein cysts. They are commonly seen in gestational trophoblastic disease, multiple gestational pregnancies, and other high HCG states. Most of them resolve spontaneously after delivery. Surgical management is only required if it is complicated by torsion or hemorrhage. 

The below image shows bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple theca luteal cysts as in hyperreactio luteinalis.


Option D- Hematometra is a condition in which menstrual outflow obstruction traps the blood and distends the uterus.  A large uterus can compress the urinary bladder, and rectum causing urinary retention and constipation. blood may get infected and lead to pyometra causing fever and leukocytosis.

The below ultrasonographic image shows a smooth, symmetric hypoechoic enlargement of the uterine cavity suggestive of hematometra.

questions.text: A person presents with the deformity shown in the picture and is unable to move the thumb away from the rest of the hand. Which of the following nerve is injured?
questions.solution:
The above picture shows ape thumb deformity. It results from median nerve palsy. Ape thumb deformity is inability to abduct the thumb due to paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle. The thumb remains parallel by the side of other fingers.

In the hand, the median nerve supplies muscles of the thenar eminence, mainly abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis and flexor pollicis brevis.

questions.text: A male patient is brought unresponsive to the emergency room following trauma to the head. CT head is shown below. What is the definitive management for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing lens-shaped hemorrhage is consistent with acute epidural hematoma. Craniotomy with emergency evacuation of the hematoma is the definitive management of this condition.

Extradural hematoma (EDH) is also known as an epidural hematoma. It is a collection of blood between the outer layer of the dura and the inner surface of the skull which is called the periosteal layer. The bleeding is most commonly due to torn middle meningeal artery.

EDH is commonly associated with a history of trauma and associated skull fracture.  It is associated with an underlying fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone.

Epidural hematoma may present with a transient loss of consciousness immediately following the trauma followed by a lucid interval, where consciousness is recovered. The patient subsequently worsens his neurological status due to continued bleeding from the site as seen in this patient. It can cause a mass effect with herniation

EDH is diagnosed with CT and MRI. CT image shows the typical bi-convex hyperdense lesion not crossing cranial sutures, but can cross venous sinuses.

The definitive management for any patient with GCS<9 and pupillary abnormalities such as anisocoria is craniotomy with emergency evacuation of the hematoma. Surgery is also recommended for patients with worsening neurological status and hematoma volume >30ml regardless of neurological status

Other options:

Option A: Hyperventilation lowers the pCO2 and lowers the intracranial pressure (ICP) because of vasoconstriction. But this may also worsen the perfusion in the brain and must be done with caution.

Option B: Intravenous mannitol may be used to lower ICP but it is not a definitive management option in this patient in a coma.

Option D: Anticoagulants are not administered in cases of EDH, especially if surgery is needed or there's a risk of ongoing bleeding. This is because anticoagulants can increase the risk of bleeding, which can exacerbate the situation in cases of traumatic brain injury.

questions.text: A young female patient presents to the gynecology OPD with complaints of malodorous discharge adherent to the vaginal wall. The gynecologist diagnoses her with bacterial vaginosis. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with bacterial vaginosis, the treatment of choice is oral metronidazole 500 mg given twice a day for 7 days.

Bacterial vaginosis is an infective condition caused by anaerobes like Gardnerella, Prevotella, and Mobiluncus species. Patients present with malodorous discharge, and minimal pruritus. Bacterial vaginosis is treated with metronidazole.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not show the finding seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
The cardiotocograph shows sinusoidal fetal heart rate pattern and is not seen in fetal head compression which shows early deceleration. Sinusoidal pattern is seen in the following conditions.

  • Fetal intracranial hemorrhage
  • Severe fetal asphyxia
  • Severe fetal anemia - Due to anti-D alloimmunization, feto-maternal haemorrhage, bleeding from vasa previa, parvovirus infection and twin-twin transfusion syndrome.
  • Administration of opioid analgesics - pethidine, morphine, alphaprodine, and butorphanol

The pattern is characterized by a stable baseline heart rate between 120-160 with regular sinusoidal oscillations. The amplitude of the oscillations is usually between 5-15 beats per minute and accelerations are absent.

Other cardiotocography patterns:

Early deceleration:

Seen in foetal head compression.

Late deceleration:

Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia.  

Variable deceleration:

Seen in umbilical cord compression.

questions.text: Project “Axshya” is in relation to controlling which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Project Axshya was launched in 2010 to control TB. Axshya means ‘free from TB’ which is the ultimate goal of the project and the national TB programme.

Project Axshya is being implemented by The International Union Against Tuberculosis and Lung Disease (known simply as The Union). The project works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between government and civil society.

The guiding principles of project Axshya are:

  • Universal access to quality TB services,
  • Community participation in TB care and control,
  • Sustainable interventions and equitable distribution of project benefits with social and gender sensitivity

World Tuberculosis Day, observed on 24 March each year, is designed to build public awareness about the global epidemic of tuberculosis and efforts to eliminate the disease. The theme for 2019 is 'It's time'.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever, night sweats, cough, and dyspnea. Lung biopsies reveal non-necrotizing granulomas. On further testing of the tissue samples, there is no evidence of acid-fast bacilli or fungal growth. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory multi-system disorder characterized by the presence of multiple non-caseating/non-necrotizing granulomas. 

Patients present with constitutional symptoms such as fever, malaise, night sweats, cough, and dyspnea of insidious onset. The lung is the most commonly affected organ in this disease. Radiographic findings are variable and hilar lymphadenopathy is seen in certain cases.

Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating the presence of non-caseating granulomas in lung biopsies along with other manifestations of this disease.

The plain radiograph below demonstrates hilar lymphadenopathy:

questions.text: You are asked to perform sequential adrenal vein sampling in a patient with bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. Which of the following is the correct sequence of veins that you will go through to test the left adrenal gland?

choices.text: Femoral vein→IVC→right renal vein→right adrenal vein
Femoral vein→IVC→left renal vein→left adrenal vein
Femoral vein→IVC→left gonadal vein→left adrenal vein

questions.solution:
The correct sequence encountered during sequential venous sampling is femoral vein→IVC→left renal vein→left adrenal vein. 

On the right side, the order is femoral vein→IVC→right adrenal vein.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the OPD with sudden onset speech difficulty, tremors, and difficulty in walking. He is noted to have a wide stepping gait. He is a known hypertensive but is not adherent to treatment. Where is the lesion most likely to be seen on neuroimaging?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of cerebellar ataxia, hence the lesion is most likely to be seen in the cerebellum. Cerebellar ataxia can be caused due to an acute vascular event such as infarction or hemorrhage.

Wide stepping gait, a broad-based unstable gait is indicative of cerebellar dysfunction. Few other notable gait abnormalities are:

  • Short stepped gait- parkinsonism
  • Scissoring gait- spasticity i.e. UMN lesion
  • High-stepped, slapping gait- posterior column or peripheral nerve disease
  • Waddling gait- proximal muscle weakness

A few of the cerebellar signs include:

  • Dysdiadokinesia / dysmetria
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Intention tremor
  • Speech - slurred or scanning
  • Hypotonia

questions.text: A young patient who suffered a large wound due to a road traffic accident was referred to you after initial wound management. As a plastic surgeon, you decide to cover the wound with the following type of graft. Which of the following is not a feature of the graft used by the plastic surgeon?

choices.text: It is also known as Thiersch graft
Only dressing is enough at donor site
This graft has the best cosmetic appearance

questions.solution:
The given image shows the procedure of obtaining a split-thickness skin graft using a handheld Humby knife. The best cosmetic appearance is generally seen with full-thickness skin grafts. 

The most preferable donor site is buttock in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

  • The graft is taken from the donor site with a handheld Humby knife or dermatome knife.
  • Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’. It can further be meshed to allow expansion.
  • Grafts will take up only on the beds which are vascularized, hence preparation of wound bed is an essential step.
  • Skin grafts are completely dependent on nutrition on the tissue over which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.
  • A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage take.
  • The presence of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci is a contraindication in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donors to full-thickness defects.
  • The donor area is dressed appropriately and the dressing is opened after 10 days and not earlier. 

The given image shows Humby's knife. The average thickness of the graft obtained from a Humbys knife is 0.3 mm.

 

Split thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft ): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts.

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft) include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. 

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft take up. 
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

  • It has a lesser degree of post graft contraction
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

questions.text: Which of the following is the measure of the strength of the association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies?
questions.solution:
A case– control study yields only odds ratio and not incidence or relative risk.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Odds ratio calculation (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • If the frequency of exposure is higher among cases, the OR will exceed 1, which indicates increased risk.
  • If the frequency is lower, then it will be <1, which can indicate possible protection.
  • If the OR is 1, then there is no association of risk with exposure or that the event is equally likely in both groups.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of painless bleeding during defecation. On examination, a pinkish mass appears at the anal orifice when the patient is asked to strain. It reduces spontaneously when the patient relaxes. What will be the grade of this hemorrhoid?
questions.solution:
Prolapse with spontaneous reduction is suggestive of second-degree hemorrhoids.

Related Pearl: Grading of hemorrhoids

GRADE

SYMPTOMS AND SIGNS

First degree

Bleeding; no prolapse

Second degree

Prolapse with spontaneous reduction

Third degree

Prolapse requiring manual reduction

Fourth degree

Prolapsed, cannot be reduced

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. The microscopic examination of urine is shown below. What is the type of stone seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows a hexagonal crystal, suggesting cystine stones. These stones are a recurrent feature in patients with cystinuria.

Crystals in urine are usually associated with kidney stones. Crystals form in the urine depends upon a variety of factors including:

  • The degree of concentration of constituent molecules
  • The urine pH
  • The presence of inhibitors of crystallization

Calcium oxalate and uric acid crystals can sometimes be found in normal urine that has been left to stand, due to crystal formation ex vivo.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: A patient in the emergency department has the following findings on ECG. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lateral wall myocardial infarction is the likely diagnosis in this patient.

The patient's ECG demonstrates elevated ST segments in lead I and aVL. In such an infarction, the left anterior descending or the left circumflex coronary is involved.

Additionally, a posterior wall myocardial infarction is also likely in this patient due to ST segment depression in lead III. Posterior wall infarctions are difficult to diagnose and usually are associated with other myocardial infarctions such as lateral wall infarction.

questions.text: An elderly man presented with a new-onset pulsatile swelling over his wrist as shown in the image. He was recently discharged after a one-month-long ICU admission for urosepsis. On examination, systolic bruit was audible and a doppler revealed bidirectional flow of blood. Which of the following is false regarding the given condition?

choices.text: Due to focal dilation in a vessel in which only the intimal layer is disrupted
Treatment includes endovascular stent insertion and thrombin therapy
Yin-yang sign is seen on doppler ultrasound of the swelling

questions.solution:
The patient most likely has a pseudoaneurysm of the radial artery due to repeated arterial blood gas sampling done in the ICU. Dilatation of vessel due to tear involving only the intima is a dissection, not a pseudoaneurysm.

In pseudoaneurysm, the intimal and medial layers are disrupted and the dilated segment of the aorta is lined by adventitia only and at times by perivascular clot. Pseudoaneurysm is most commonly seen due to repeated arterial puncture for blood sampling or catheterization procedures where there is an increased chance of arterial wall injury. It is usually pulsatile and systolic bruit can be heard on auscultation.

Doppler ultrasound reveals bidirectional, 'to-and-fro' flow of blood which is known as the yin-yang sign. Treatment options include endovascular stent insertion, ultrasound-guided thrombin injection, and surgical repair.

Note: A true aneurysm involves all three layers of the vessel wall.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was diagnosed with a urogenital tumor. History revealed that the patient had cryptorchidism in his childhood. Which of the following tumors is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The commonest cancer in patients who had cryptorchidism is seminoma.

The cancer risk for adults after cryptorchidism in childhood is 5–10 times greater than normal. The most common cancer is seminoma.

Seminoma:

  • It is the most common type of GCT (~50% of GCTs). The peak incidence is seen in the fourth decade.
  • It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma, or the pineal gland tumor termed germinoma.
  • Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin and negative for cytokeratin.

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis.

The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance). The sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate.

Other options:
Option B: Leydig cell tumors are sex-cord stromal cell tumors of the testis. They predominantly secrete androgens and in some cases estrogen and corticosteroids as well. The most common presenting features in prepubertal children are painless testicular swelling and precocious puberty. 
Option C: Sertoli cell tumors are sex-cord stromal cell tumors of the testis. They are usually hormonally inactive and present only as a painless testicular mass. It is associated with Carneys complex, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, and familial adenomatosis polyposis syndrome.
Option D: Teratoma can be seen in infants and children after yolk sac tumors. It consists of derivatives of all three germ layers. It includes islands of bronchial epithelium, neural tissue, muscle, islands of cartilage, clusters of squamous epithelium, etc. 

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP:

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor
  •  AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is a false positive hydrostatic test in fetus seen?
questions.solution:
The hydrostatic test is falsely positive in the case of putrefied fetus.

Hydrostatic test is done to determine whether the newborn has respired or not. It is also known as floatation test/ Breslau’s first life test/ Raygat’s test.

If the lung pieces float in water, it means that respiration has taken place, indicating a live birth. If the pieces sink, respiration has not taken place, which means it is stillborn.

An unrespired lung (stillbirth) may float, giving a false positive test, due to gases of decomposition, as seen in putrefaction. 

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Fetus is macerated or mummified
  • Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation
  • Stomach contains milk
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

questions.text:
Choose the option with correct matches:
Term Description
1. Puppe's Rule a. Surgical intervention of a firearm wound leading to an artefact

2. Kennedy Phenomena

 b. Planting a bullet inside a stab wound
3. Rayalseema Phenomenon c. Relationship between trauma and new growth
4. Ewing's Postulates d. Chronological sequence of bullets fired
questions.solution:
The correct match would be as follows:

Term Description
1. Puppe's Rule a.Chronological sequence of bullets fired

2. Kennedy Phenomena

 b. Surgical intervention of a firearm wound leading to an artefact
3. Rayalseema Phenomenon c.Planting a bullet inside a stab wound 
4. Ewing's Postulates d. Relationship between trauma and new growth

Puppe's rule: Helps in determining the sequence of bullets to hit the skull, when there are multiple bullet injuries to skull. The fracture line resulting from the later bullet will typically stop at the previously formed one.

Kennedy's phenomenon: Surgical intervention of a firearm wound leading to an artefac. The evaluation of wound as entry or exit wound becomes difficult.

Rayalaseema phenomenon: Here a person is killed by stab injury, and a bullet is implanted inside to mislead the investigation.

Ewing's postulates: Establishes a relationship between trauma and new growth.

The following postulates should be satisfied before a relationship between trauma and new growth is accepted:

  • Evidence of previous integrity of the injured part.
  • Undeniable and adequate trauma must be proved.
  • There must be a proof of reasonable time interval between injury and appearance of tumour.
  • Disease must develop at the exact site of injury.
  • The nature of the tumour must be proved.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with a 9-month history of weight loss, abdominal cramps, intermittent diarrhea. On examination, there is a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant. Stool cultures are normal. Colonoscopy shows the presence of skip lesions.
