questions.text: Extramammary Paget's disease is a type of ____
questions.solution:
• Extramammary Paget's disease is a form of intraepidermal adenocarcinoma, which may occur in the genital, perianal regions or in cutaneous sites rich in apocrine glands such as the axilla.
  • Approximately 25% of the cases are associated with an underlying in situ or invasive neoplasm.
  • Surgical excision forms the basis of treatment.

questions.text: A pregnant women comes with obstructed labour and is grossly dehydrated. Investigations reveal fetal demise. What will be the management?
questions.solution:
The best management in the above case is a cesarean section as it is a case of obstructed labour.

Management of obstructed labor:

  • IV fluids for dehydration.
  • Antibiotics to prevent infection.
  • Relieve obstruction by cesarean section
  • Alive fetus ----> immediate cesarean section
  • Dead fetus---->cesarean section

questions.text:
Match the following:
1 - Kleptomania A - Intense desire to drink alcoholic drinks
2 - Pyromania B - Intense desire to mutilate
3 - Mutilomania C - Intense desire to steal items of trivial value
4 - Dipsomania D - Intense desire to burn things
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

Impulse control disorders are characterized by the repeated failure to resist an impulse, drive, or urge to perform an act that is rewarding to the person, at least in the short-term, despite consequences such as long-term harm either to the individual or to others; marked distress about the behavior pattern; or significant impairment in personal, family, social, educational, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

It includes

  1. Pyromania
  2. Kleptomania 
  3. Compulsive sexual behavior disorder
  4. Intermittent explosive disorder

Kleptomania is the repeated failure to resist impulses to steal objects that are of no value to the person. The individual can usually afford the object or does not need it, but it is the act of stealing itself that is the goal. The stolen objects are usually given away, returned, or kept hidden. The act is not planned and is carried out alone.

Pyromania is the deliberate setting of fires on more than one occasion. 

Pyromania is significantly associated with the following:

  • Substance abuse disorder (especially alcoholism).
  • Affective disorders (depression or bipolar)
  • Other impulse control disorders, such as kleptomania in female firesetters.
  • Personality disturbances, such as borderline personality disorders.
  • Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder and learning disabilities in childhood pyromania.

Mutilomania is an irresistible impulse to mutilate animals.

Dipsomania is an irresistible impulse to drink alcohol at periodic intervals.

questions.text: A man in a restaurant suddenly begins choking on his food. The following procedure was performed by another patron at the restaurant. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The image shows a person standing behind with arms placed around the choking person's lower chest, giving abdominal thrusts, which is suggestive of Heimlich's maneuver.

The Heimlich maneuver (also known as subdiaphragmatic abdominal thrusts or abdominal thrusts) is done for an adult or a child (1-8 years) with foreign body airway obstruction (FBAO). It is not recommended for FBAO relief in infants. 

The rescuer should stand or kneel behind the patient and wrap his arms around the patient’s waist. A fist is made with one hand and using the other hand, the fist is driven into the patient’s abdomen with a rapid, forceful inward and upward thrust to dislodge the foreign body. This is continued until the foreign body is expelled or if the patient becomes unresponsive. 

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).

 Other options:

Option B: Back slaps or back blows can also be used to relieve FBAO. They are given between the shoulder blades using the heel of the rescuer’s hand, and up to 5 are given. If there is a failure of the back slaps to relieve the obstruction, up to 5 abdominal thrusts can be given. 

Infants (<1 year) should be treated with alternating 5 back blows and then 5 chest thrusts. The infant's torso is placed on the rescuer's nondominant arm. The procedure is depicted in the image below.

Option C: Chest thrusts can be used as an alternative to the Heimlich maneuver for pregnant women or markedly obese patients. The patient is supine, and the rescuer should kneel close to the victim’s side. Hands are placed in the same manner as is done to perform CPR chest compressions. Each thrust is given in such a way as to relieve the obstruction. 

Option D: The blind finger sweep can be done in unresponsive adults with complete foreign body airway obstruction. With the patient's face up, the mouth is opened by grasping both the tongue and lower jaw and lifting the mandible. The index finger is inserted along the inside of the cheek and using a hooking action, the foreign body is dislodged and removed. The blind finger sweep should be avoided in infants since it may push the object further inside the airway

questions.text: Which clinical examination is being done in the picture?
questions.solution:
The clinical examination elicited is Fluid thrill.

The fluid thrill is elicited to clinically diagnose ascites.

It is not a reliable sign and is only felt when there is a large amount of fluid under tension.

Method: The patient is placed supine and his abdomen is exposed after consent. Place one hand of the examiner flat over the lumbar region while an assistant's hand is kept firmly on the midline of the abdomen with the side of his hand kept longitudinally. This is done to dampen any impulse that can be transmitted via the fat of the abdominal wall. Now the examiner flicks or taps the opposite side of the abdomen where his palm is not resting and a fluid thrill or wave is felt on the resting hand.

Clinical signs associated with ascites:

Finding Minimum volume(ml)
Puddle sign positive 120 
Shifting dullness 500
Fluid thrill 1500 

Note:

The cardinal clinical sign for ascites is shifting dullness.

questions.text: A plastic surgeon uses a Wolfe graft to cover a smaller area of skin defect. All of the following are true regarding these grafts except:
questions.solution:
Wolfes graft is a type of full-thickness graft. The best cosmetic appearance is seen with a full-thickness graft.

Full-thickness skin grafts include the epidermis and the complete layer of the dermis. They are used for smaller areas of skin replacement where good elastic skin is required.

Full-thickness grafts are associated with,

  • The greatest amount of primary contraction,
  • The least amount of secondary contraction,
  • The highest durability, and
  • The best cosmetic appearance.

As a result, they are frequently used in reconstructing superficial wounds of the face and the hands.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhoea. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history along with the moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

In Asherman syndrome, oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, abortion and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae.

The synechiae are caused by the following factors:

  • Vigorous curettage following postpartum haemorrhage or abortion
  • Tubercular endometritis
  • Uterine infections with or without intra-uterine device

Asherman syndrome:

It refers to the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages for elective abortion, tuberculous endometritis, and uterine surgeries.

Depending on the degree of scarring, patients may have amenorrhea, hypomenorrhea, or recurrent pregnancy loss because of inadequate placentation.

Hysterosalpingography is performed to assess the uterine cavity and tubal patency. Intrauterine adhesions are characteristically seen as irregular angulated filling defects in the uterine cavity with a classic 'moth-eaten' appearance. 

Definitive diagnosis (gold standard) and management are done by hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the surgical treatment of choice.

Hormonal assays also aid in the diagnosis of anatomical causes of amenorrhea such as Asherman syndrome. All women with amenorrhea in the reproductive age group are considered pregnant unless proven otherwise by negative urinary or serum β-HCG levels. Once negative for pregnancy, further testing is done by a progesterone challenge test.

This test is done by administering medroxyprogesterone acetate as a 10-mg daily oral dose for 10 days. If the woman bleeds, then she is assumed to produce estrogen and to have a developed endometrium, and the presence of a patent outflow tract is confirmed. If she does not bleed, then she is given estrogen followed by progesterone treatment in the form of combined OCPs. If she fails to bleed after completing the 21 hormone-containing pills, then an anatomic abnormality is diagnosed such as Asherman syndrome.

questions.text: A patient with HIV has a CD4 count of 170/ μL. He complains of breathlessness for the past week. The patient's chest radiograph is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows symmetric interstitial infiltrates mainly in the perihilar region. This finding along with the CD4 count of 170 cells /μL makes pneumocystis pneumonia the most likely diagnosis.

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients. It usually occurs when the CD4 count falls below 200 cells/μL.

Patients usually present with fever and nonproductive cough with progressive shortness of breath. It can also affect other organs like lymph nodes, spleen, and liver. The classic radiographic appearance consists of diffuse bilateral symmetric interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar. CT will show diffuse ground-glass opacities.

Giemsa stain, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains demonstrate trophozoites. The cyst wall appears black with Gomori's methenamine silver stain. Shown below is an image of the Gomori’s methenamine silver staining showing crescent-shaped cysts resembling the crushed ping-pong balls of P. jirovecii.

Other options

Option A- Mycobacterium avium complex infection is generally seen when the CD4 count falls less than 50 cells/μL. CT scan of the infected lung will show peribronchial inflammation, which gives rise to a tree in a bud appearance (small round structures attached to linear structures). In severe cases, there might be bronchiectasis and cavity formation.

Below image- Tree in bud appearance which is indicated by an arrowhead.

Option B- Histoplasmosis occurs when the CD4 count falls below 150 cells/μL and high risk populations in endemic areas or those with occupational exposure. Chest radiograph shows the signs of pneumonitis with prominent hilar or mediastinal adenopathy.

Option D- Pneumococcal pneumonia commonly appears as lobar or segmental consolidation. In some, it can involve more than one lobe. It can have pleural effusion and empyema in severe cases.

Below image- Consolidation in a streptococcal pneumonia

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the clinic with gastritis. He gives a history of taking too many NSAIDs for his chronic back pain. The use of NSAIDs impairs the gastric mucosal defense mechanism primarily by:
questions.solution:
The NSAIDs impair the mucosal defense mechanism primarily by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.

Almost all the mucosal defense mechanisms are primarily mediated by prostaglandins synthesized by the gastric mucosal cells. NSAIDs inhibit the cyclooxygenases (COX 1 and 2) which mediate prostaglandin synthesis, thereby causing impairment of mucosal defense.

NSAIDs also decrease nitric oxide synthesis(responsible for vasodilation) and have an irritant effect on the gastric mucosa but inhibition of COX enzymes/ prostaglandin synthesis is the most prominent factor.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman complains of yellowish discoloration of her axillary sweat and staining of the clothing for 15 days. She has no other complaints. On examination, yellowish concretions are noted on the hair shafts of the left axilla which have formed hard nodular masses. Underlying skin is normal. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of trichomycosis axillaris which is caused by Corynebacterium tenuis.

It is a superficial infection of axillary and pubic hairs with the formation of yellow, black, or red nodular concretions on the hair shaft. The axillary sweat may be yellow, black, or red according to the color of the concretions, and the clothing may be stained.

The condition is usually asymptomatic and the patient is often unaware of its presence. The use of an effective antiperspirant such as aluminum chloride is a rapid means of therapy. 

The image below shows trichomycosis axillaris in the axilla with a close-up view of nodules on the hair shaft.

questions.text: CT done for a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of sterile pyuria with CT showing right-sided putty kidney points to renal tuberculosis. 

Putty kidney refers to the amorphous dystrophic calcification seen over the entire kidney during the end stage of genitourinary TB. 

Genitourinary tuberculosis is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream. It occurs either due to reinfection or reactivation of old TB.

CT is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB. 

ATT is given to all patients with genitourinary TB. Nephrectomy is the preferred treatment in patients with putty/ cement kidneys.

Option D: Nephrocalcinosis refers to the deposition of calcium salts in the kidney parenchyma and tubules.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy was brought to the psychiatrist by his parents. The parents reported that the child frequently lies at home and in school, misbehaves with the teacher, often bullies the younger kids, and has been caught stealing money on multiple occasions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this boy is conduct disorder.

Conduct disorder is diagnosed when at least 3 characteristic behaviors have been present within the previous 12 months, with at least 1 present in the past 6 months.

The onset of Conduct Disorder:

  • Childhood-onset type: Individuals show at least one symptom characteristic of conduct disorder before the age of 10 years.
  • Adolescent-onset type: Individuals show no symptom characteristic of conduct disorder before the age of 10 years.
  • Unspecified onset: Criteria for a diagnosis of conduct disorder are met, but there is not enough information available to determine whether the onset of the first symptom was before or after the age of 10 years.
DSM-5 criteria for Conduct Disorder  
Aggression towards people and animals

Initiating physical fights, bullying, threatening, or intimidating others

Using a weapon to cause serious harm to others

Being physically cruel to people

Being physically cruel to animals

Stealing while confronting a victim

Forcing someone into sexual activity
Destruction of property

Setting fires

Intentionally destroying the property of others
Serious violation of rules

Running away overnight at least twice or once without returning for a lengthy period.

Being truant from school often starting before age 13.

Frequently staying out at night despite parental prohibitions starting before age 13
Deceitfulness or theft

Frequently lying to obtain goods or favors

Breaking into a car or building

Stealing items of nontrivial value without confronting a victim

Other options:

: Oppositional defiant disorder(ODD):

  • Persistent pattern, lasting at least 6 months, of negativistic, hostile, and defiant attitude/behavior towards adults, including arguments, temper outbursts, vindictiveness, and deliberate annoyance.
  • Seen in children less than 10 years of age.
  • The symptoms must be present for 6 months, during which 4 or more of the following have to be present:
    • Argues with others
    • Loses temper
    • Blames others
    • Easily annoyed
    • Refuses and defies listening to adults

NOTE: Unlike conduct disorder, children with ODD do not indulge in destructive and physically harmful activities.

Option C: If conduct disorder persists beyond 18 years of age the child is diagnosed with an antisocial personality disorder.

Option D: In disruptive mood dysregulation disorder the child presents with severe, recurrent temper outbursts out of proportion to the situation. The child is constantly angry and irritable between outbreaks. Onset is before 10 years of age.

questions.text: The most common cause of skin graft failure is ____

choices.text: Poor quality of the recipient bed

questions.solution:
The most common cause of skin graft failure is hematoma under the graft, where the blood clot is a barrier to contact of the graft and bed for revascularization.

Other causes are shearing or movement of the graft on the bed, infection, poor quality of the recipient bed, and characteristics of the graft itself, such as thickness or vascularity of the donor site.

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  • Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  • Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  • Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

questions.text: Wernicke-Korsakoff psychosis is seen due to the deficiency of ______.
questions.solution:
Wernicke-Korsakoff psychosis is seen due to the deficiency of thiamine. Thiamine is a cofactor for several important enzymes and is also involved in the conduction of the axon potential and synaptic transmission.

Wernicke's encephalopathy/alcoholic encephalopathy is an acute neurological disorder.

The triad of symptoms seen is (GOA):

  • Global Confusion
  • Ophthalmoplegia ( first symptom to improve with thiamine +dextrose infusion)
  • Ataxia

Treatment

It is a medical emergency and requires immediate administration of thiamine 100 mg IV or IM for 3 days followed by two to three times a day orally for 1 to 2 weeks.

Glucose infusions may precipitate Wernicke’s disease in a previously unaffected patient or cause a rapid worsening of an early form of the disease. For this reason, thiamine should be administered to all alcoholic patients requiring parenteral glucose.

questions.text:
A 23 yr old gravida 1, para 0 at 25 weeks gestation, presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 days. BP-104/72mm Hg, PR-72bpm.There is generalized edema. Peripheral smear shows hemolysis. Lab values are as follows:
Leukocyte count: 10,500/mm3
Platelet count: 62000/mm3
Hematocrit: 26%
AST: 90 IU/L
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is HELLP syndrome.

The typical presentation of right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, lab findings of thrombocytopenia, low hematocrit, and peripheral smear finding of hemolysis, point towards a diagnosis of  HELLP ( Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) syndrome.

Although related to preeclampsia, hypertension and proteinuria may be absent or minimal in HELLP syndrome.

Tennessee criteria used in the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome :

  • Platelet count <1 lakh,
  • AST >70 IU/L,
  • LDH >600 IU/L

Risk factors for HELLP syndrome include

  • Preeclampsia
  • abnormal placentation
  • family history of HELLP syndrome
  • elevated levels of fetal mRNA for FLT l (vascular endothelial growth factor rfi­ receptor 1) and
  • Multiparity
  • Maternal age >34 years
  • European descent
  • History of previous poor pregnancy outcomes

Laboratory evaluation in HELLP:

  • Complete blood cell (CBC) count: Thrombocytopenia, anemia with possible reticulocytosis
  • Coagulation studies: Normal prothrombin time, 50% may have prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time
  • Peripheral smear: Schistocytes, helmet cells, and burr cells secondary to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Serum aspartate aminotransferase/alanine aminotransferase (AST/ALT) levels: Elevated secondary to liver dysfunction
  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level: Elevated secondary to liver dysfunction or hemolysis
  • Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN)/creatinine with acute renal failure
  • Bilirubin level: Increased secondary to hemolysis
  • Haptoglobin level: Decreased secondary to hemolysis
  • Fibrinogen levels: Low secondary to increased coagulation
  • D-dimer: Increased due to fibrinolysis/DIC

HELLP syndrome may lead to the development of DIC which manifests as increased fibrin split products and decreased fibrinogen levels.

Other options:

Disorder

 AST (SGOT) U/L Bilirubin (mg/dL)
Cholestasis of pregnancy Up to 200 1–5
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy 200–800 4–10
Hepatitis 2000+ 5–20

questions.text: A male patient who is suffering from a psychotic disorder is on antipsychotic, antidepressant and antihypertensive treatment. He suddenly developed tachycardia and chest tightness. On evaluation he had metabolic acidosis. ECG showed widened QRS complex and prolonged QT interval. Which of the following drugs is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of torsades de pointes. Only amitriptyline causes this condition, among the above drugs.

Torsades de pointes (French: twisting of points) is a life-threatening form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulating baseline on ECG.

Related Pearl: Drugs causing QT prolongation and torsades de pointes

Drugs Associated with QT Prolongation and Torsades de Pointes:

Antiarrhythmics:

  • Sotalol
  • Amiodarone
  • Quinidine
  • Procainamide
  • Dofetilide
  • Ibutilide

Antimicrobials:

  • Levofloxacin
  • Ciprofloxacin
  • Gatifloxacin
  • Moxifloxacin
  • Clarithromycin
  • Erythromycin
  • Ketoconazole
  • Itraconazole
  • Rilpivirine

Antidepressants:

  • Amitriptyline
  • Desipramine
  • Imipramine
  • Doxepin
  • Fluoxetine
  • Sertraline
  • Venlafaxine

Antipsychotics:

  • Haloperidol
  • Droperidol
  • Quetiapine
  • Ziprasidone
  • Thioridazine

Others:

  • Cisapride
  • Sumatriptan
  • Zolmitriptan
  • Arsenic
  • Dolasetron
  • Methadone

questions.text: The empty delta sign is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The empty delta sign is a CT sign of cerebral venous thrombosis.

The 'empty delta' sign is a CT sign of dural venous sinus thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus, where the thrombus becomes less dense and the contrast outlines a triangular filling defect (clot) within the sinus lumen. It is only described with contrast-enhanced CT-scan (CECT) or MRI with contrast (not with non-contrast CT(NCCT) or non-contrast MRI).

On doing an NCCT scan, an acutely thrombosed sinus appears hyperdense and expanded. This is called the 'delta sign'. 

 

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhages

questions.text: An 18-month-child is brought to the pediatrician with the history of distension of abdomen and delayed mental development. On examination, the cornea is cloudy and radiograph of the child is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
As the child presents with mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly and cloudy cornea and given x-ray shows a J-shaped sella and a thickened calvaria, the most likely diagnosis is Hurler Syndrome.

Hurler syndrome is also known as MPS 1. This is due to the defect in the α-L Iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparin sulphate and dermatan sulphate.

Radiological features in Hurler Syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • J-shaped sella (seen in above radiograph)
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs (seen below)
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

 

Phenotypical features of Hurler's syndrome and Hunter's syndrome are quite similar; however, Hunter syndrome (deficiency of iduronate sulfatase enzyme) is generally less severe than Hurler syndrome and can be clinically differentiated by a lack of corneal clouding.

questions.text: GOBI FFF strategy, proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) includes all of the following components except:
questions.solution:
GOBI FFF strategy, proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) includes all of the given components except Female empowerment.

Related Pearl: GOBI–FFF Strategy

This strategy was proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF)

  • G – Growth monitoring with growth charts
  • O – Oral rehydration therapy for diarrhoea and dehydration
  • B – Breastfeeding
  • I – Immunization of children
  • F – Family planning and birth spacing
  • F – Food supplementation
  • F ­– Female literacy promotion

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Menopause?

choices.text: Premature menopause is before the age of 38
Menopause setting after 55 years is delayed menopause
Average age of menopause is 47 years

questions.solution:
Menopause seting before the age of 40 is termed as premature menopause.

Other features of menopause :

  • The average age of menopause is 47 years. (Option D)
  • The range of menopause age is 45 to 50 years. 
  • Menopause setting after 55 years is delayed menopause. (Option C)
  • Menopause sets in when follicle number falls below 1000.
  • Menopause age is not related to age at menarche, race, number of pregnancy, socio-economic status, or oral contraceptive pills.
  • Menopause is directly related to smoking and genetic disposition. 
  • Smoking induces premature menopause. (Option A)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who is in the third trimester of pregnancy started to experience pain in her left leg. She also noticed that her left leg was turning pale and edematous as given in the image below. What is the cause of this condition?

choices.text: Femoral vein thrombosis and lymphatic obstruction
Due to pressure exerted by uterus on the iliac veins

questions.solution:
The patient is having phlegmasia alba dolens also known milk leg or white leg. It is due to ileofemoral deep vein thrombosis.

It is usually seen in pregnant women and in individuals at risk of developing deep vein thrombosis. They typically present with painful, oedematous, and pale lower limb that blanches to touch. The lack of cyanosis differentiates this entity from phlegmasia cerulea dolens.

In phlegmasia alba dolens, the thrombosis involves only major deep venous channels of the extremity, thus sparing collateral veins. The venous drainage is decreased but still present.

In phlegmasia cerulea dolens, the thrombosis extends to collateral veins, resulting in severe venous congestion with massive fluid sequestration and more significant edema.

Both phlegmasia cerulea dolens and phlegmasia alba dolens results from acute massive deep vein thrombosis and can be complicated by venous gangrene.

Edema of pregnancy does not present with pain in the lower limbs but edema due to pressure exerted by the gravid uterus on the iliac veins.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with grade 2 splenic injury following blunt trauma to the abdomen. On examination, there are no signs of bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this child?
questions.solution:
Conservative management is the most appropriate management in this child.

Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) is usually followed in:

  • Stable patients with no active bleeding
  • Patients younger than 55 years of age
  • Patients with grade I, II, III injuries.

Any patient who is hemodynamically unstable, has active bleeding, and has grade IV and V splenic injury should be managed by surgery.

questions.text: An immunocompromised patient from a lower-income household presents with mild fever which is present only during the night and associated with weight loss. She has a swelling on her neck as shown in the image below which is soft, and non-tender. The fluctuation test is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of immunosuppression, symptoms of fever at night, weight loss, and the neck finding of an ulcer with undermined edges is suggestive of tubercular lymphadenitis.

The image shows long-standing tubercular adenitis with a sinus. 

Tuberculous cervical lymphadenitis:

  • Any group of lymph nodes can be involved.
  • Symptoms include evening pyrexia, malaise, and cough (from pulmonary tuberculosis) while in children, failure to thrive can be seen. 
  • A matted lymph nodal mass is the typical clinical feature.
  • In later stages the mass may be cystic, denoting an abscess.
  • The abscess denotes underlying caseation and does not show any features of inflammation – hence it is called a 'cold abscess'.
  • The pus is initially confined by the deep cervical fascia, but after weeks or months, this may become eroded at one point and the pus flows through the small opening into the space beneath the superficial fascia. The process has now reached the stage of a ‘collar stud abscess'.
  • An abscess may burst through the skin to form an ulcer with undermined edges which is typical of a tubercular ulcer with undermined edges and can develop into a discharging sinus.
  • Diagnosis is by the culture of pus and biopsy of the lymph node.
  • The involvement of other systems must be excluded.
  • Treatment- antitubercular drugs.
